Evan checked the light board and the sound levels and the prop cabinet that wanted to be a closet someday and found his own handwriting where Tess had made him make it yesterday, his capital letters more certain than he felt. Vee arrived with wet hair and a book under her arm that said “Birds of Ohio” as if words could domesticate their subjects, and when she saw him she nodded without flourishes and said, “You all right,” in a tone that made it easy to tell the truth.

“I am a man held together by tape,” he said, and she smiled without breaking stride and said, “Then we’re all spiritual cousins,” and disappeared to argue with a costume that had decided to be silk when it had been bought as cotton. The smallness of the day steadied him, a list he could put into his mouth and swallow without choking. He said “Half hour” into the microphone and liked the power of it; he said “Fifteen” and tried not to think of gates and boarding groups; he said “Five” and felt his heart settle into a tempo that had nothing to do with engines and everything to do with intention.

The second night brought different strangers, and strangers are always different in their sameness. A woman in the third row wore a cardigan like armor and let herself cry when the red fabric moved as if her body had been waiting for permission; an older man laughed at a line about grandmothers as if laughter were a rebellion he could still afford. Evan took them in as a single creature with a hundred heads, an animal that needed to be led to water and told it was allowed to drink. He fumbled a sound cue by a breath and nobody died; Tess squeezed his shoulder afterward as if to reward him for being human in public. He felt the familiar urge to apologize for an error he’d trained entire systems out of, and he stepped on it like a lit match and let it smoke and be nothing.

After the show they stood in the green room that wasn’t, a rectangle with a microwave that had gone to college twice and a couch that had acquired a reputation. Marcus handed around grapes as if he were Santa reinvented as a fruit bowl and Vee ate them with a precision that made you think she had rules about spheres. Tess counted the cash in the donation jar with her lips moving and said something rude about the generosity of people who would spend fifteen dollars on a drink and bring her three in crumpled bills, but she said it with love, like a mother scolding a thief who steals for reasons she understands. Evan sat on a flight case and let the buzz run out of him the way carbonation does when you let a bottle breathe, and when he looked up he saw that Colm was in the doorway again as if the building had asked him to be one of its doorframes.

“Good house,” Colm said to Tess, and Tess snorted and said, “I’ve seen worse and I’ve seen it with mildew,” and then she turned to Evan and said, “Your voice for the ‘Standby’ is getting lower, which makes everyone calm, so keep drinking coffee or whatever makes you less of a boy, but not so much that you start thinking you’re in charge of anything.” Evan said, “Yes, ma’am,” and Vee said, “He’s an agreeable hinge,” and the word made him grin in a way that felt like a borrowed coat that fit better than expected.

They walked out into the alley under a sky that was doing that thing Ohio skies do where they look like they’ve been ironed by someone who resented the chore. The news vans had gone to cover something that wasn’t art, and the dumpsters smelled like bread and ghosts; someone had painted over a tag on the brick with a patch of color that didn’t match, and now the color was the tag. Colm looked thinner in the sodium light, the warmth of him drawn tight to save heat, and he said, “Bridge is quiet,” before Evan could ask, and then he said, “It won’t stay. But you have your show, so we will let polite things be polite and impolite things be less interesting for as long as we can.”

“What is it when it isn’t a mark,” Evan asked, because his skepticism had the odd habit of turning into curiosity when he wasn’t looking. “When it’s a door, I mean. What is it a door to.”

“Depends who drew it and who made the first noise,” Colm said, as if he were explaining traffic patterns. “Sometimes it’s a door to someone else’s breath. Sometimes it’s a door to the part of the town that doesn’t like us. Sometimes it’s nothing and I am a fool with chalk, which is my preferred diagnosis. Do your hands shake when you press ‘Go’ or are you a statue yet.”

“I’m a statue someone put a motor in,” Evan said, and Colm laughed, not because it was funny but because it was precise, and then he told Evan about a woman who had hired him to find her locket and had ended up finding her own patience instead, and the story ended with a cat that had adopted a plant and made it thrive. They stood in that spill of light that pretended to be safety and listened to the traffic two streets over argue with itself, and neither of them said the word blood because they didn’t need to.

The next morning, Arthur found a notice on the neighborhood forum printed out by a neighbor who believed paper to be more real than screens, and he brought it to the table with the air of a man delivering a summons. The flier had a photo of a stencil on a brick wall, not the bridge exactly but the same hand, the same insistence on red, the line of a palm and the suggestion of fingers like a schoolchild’s turkey drawing. The caption said, “Vandalism or art? Join the conversation,” and there was a time and a place and the earnestness of people who want all problems to be solvable by chairs arranged in a circle. June clicked her tongue and said, “If they get me in a circle I’ll stand up, you know I will,” and Arthur said, “They will hate you for speaking plain,” and June said, “They always do; I’ll bring cookies.”

Evan looked at the picture and felt the same cartoon slide in his stomach he had felt at the bridge, smaller in daylight but there. Colm took the paper and looked at it long enough for the coffee to go cold and said, “They didn’t mean it,” like a judge pronouncing guilt with compassion. “Most people who make doors don’t intend to. They mean to hang a picture and they open the wall instead.” He folded the paper neatly so the red hand was hidden and put it in his jacket pocket and said, “I think we’ll go to that conversation, don’t you, June,” and June gave him a look that combined all the ways she had of loving him and said, “We do not let the babies talk by themselves.”

Tess hated meetings because meetings were two steps away from grants, and grants made her stomach acid perform acrobatics for audiences, but she went to this one because the theater had a stake in any red thing in this town. She wore a shirt that said “Gaffer Tape Is My Love Language,” and when someone made a joke about it she let them and then talked about the cost of replacing bulbs in the work lights and everyone in the room watched her like they would buy her a bulb and a steak if they could. The gathering was held in a church basement that had learned to smell like coffee regardless of who was drinking it, and the chairs had been arranged in a circle that wanted to be a net. Vee came and took notes on a piece of paper she would later lose; Marcus brought the hat as if he thought it could serve as a talking stick; Sophie threaded a needle and did not comment. Evan sat near the back with Colm because he wanted to see who turned their heads when someone said “door.”

The town showed up like a family asked to discuss a will: eager, anxious, pretending they weren’t thinking about what they’d get to take home. A teacher spoke about art as provocation and her students who wanted to be seen and hadn’t been; a man from the city muttered about property values and vandalism and hinted at fines like a magician forcing a card; a woman who worked at the pharmacy told a story about a boy who had come in with paint on his fingers and had asked for tape and gauze and had flinched when the automatic doors opened. June said, “Maybe you make a person less lonely and they won’t need to make the wall less lonely,” and Arthur said, “Or maybe you do both because people are complicated,” and someone clapped and then apologized for clapping because the room had not signed a contract about applause.

When it was Colm’s turn—or rather, when he made it his turn by standing and making the room admit he was tall—he spoke in that voice of his that widened the aisles. He said, “Maybe treat the walls like people, too. Maybe tell them you see them. Paint the thing you want to look at when you head home, and if it isn’t a hand, all right. If it is, ask whose hand. Ask what it thinks it’s reaching for.” He didn’t say the word door. He didn’t say the words stay out or stay there or stay in your house. He said, “Don’t make a mark you can’t clean,” and the room took the sentence into itself like bread.

A boy in the second row who had cut his hair to look like he had not tried spoke, his voice an apology and a dare. He said, “It was me,” though no one had asked the question that bluntly, and the teachers in the room put their hands in their laps and decided not to rush forward to claim him. He said, “I thought it would make a hole people could put their eyes in,” and everyone except Evan heard this and thought he meant attention, and Evan heard this and thought he meant exactly what he said. He said, “I didn’t know it would smell,” and at that word something in Evan’s back teeth ached with the memory of rocket fuel that wasn’t, with pennies that weren’t, with the sweetness that had first made his heart bolt.

After the meeting, which adjourned because the coffee ran out and the room had had its say, Evan walked with the boy out into the small social weather of the parking lot. Colm followed at a distance because he could be generous like that when it mattered. The boy picked at his thumb cuticle like it was responsible, and Evan recognized the age of the movement; he had been that age with wheels in his head and only one road inviting him. “You opened something you didn’t mean to,” Evan said, so even the boy could not misunderstand. “You’re going to be careful now. You’re going to clean what you can. You’re going to draw things you can take back.”

The boy looked at him like he had been told by a stranger that he had a father somewhere and that the father was neither hero nor villain but a man who knew how to tighten a bolt. “Do you know how,” he said, the vulnerable nakedness of the question making itself an animal between them. “Do you know how to take back.”

“Sometimes,” Evan said, and felt the shame of the sometimes like a perfume he didn’t want and couldn’t wash off. “I know someone who knows. He’s annoying and he’s kind and he thinks chalk is a religion.”

“Chalk is for teachers,” the boy said, bravado injecting itself like sugar, and Evan laughed and said, “Exactly,” and he saw the boy picture a room with a blackboard and calm, and he saw the way that image tightened the strings in his neck and loosened others. Colm drifted close then, as if he had been invited by an invisible hands-clasp, and he said to the boy, “Come by the Evergreen after five if you can stand the smell of sawdust married to ancient coffee. We’ll show you where the doors are supposed to be.”

The day after that the thing came inside, which was inevitable because everything loves an audience. It did not knock on the literal door or throw itself at the box office or demand a ticket; it came in on someone’s shoes and someone else’s breath and the idea that had been shaped at a bridge and a brick and a flier. It showed up as a pattern first, a series of small red thumbprints on the edge of a prop table, nothing grotesque, just the quiet residue of a hundred handled motions coalescing into an iris. Sophie made a noise in her throat and reached for a wipe; Tess said, “Not yet,” and Evan put his hand on the table and felt, absurdly, a faint pulse, as if the wood were reciting something it had just learned.

He didn’t stop the rehearsal; he would not have dared, and besides, it would have been the wrong spell. He let the run go on and did his job and pressed “Go” and “Stop” when asked and carried water to a person who had decided they never needed water and was wrong. At break he stood by the table with the red freckles and said, “Hold,” not for the room, but to the idea that wanted to become larger. He said it softly and then said, “Stay,” under his breath the way you say it to a dog in a shape you hope the dog likes. He found Sheila’s old chalk in the drawer with her cough drops and a button shaped like a cat, and he drew the little cup shape next to the furthest smear and then another near the next. He did not draw circles around anything; he did not imprison. He drew places for things to go when they were tired of being mischief.

Vee watched him and said, “We let you play with the holy markers now,” and he said, “Don’t tell Tess or she’ll charge me a rental fee,” and Vee said, “She’ll charge you and then take you to lunch.” She reached out without touching the chalk lines and said, “What is it that you and your brother do when you’re not selling tickets to stories,” and he said, “We ask rooms to behave,” and she nodded as if she had been doing that all her life with her face and her hands and had been waiting for a name for it.

The boy from the meeting—Noah, as soon as he said it it made sense, because he had a float to him, an ark quality, something that moved even when still—showed up that afternoon wearing a shirt with paint on it placed like punctuation. He stood at the edge of the stage like someone waiting to be picked last and first, and Tess, who saw everyone before they showed up, looked at him and said, “You’re late if you’re early, that’s how this works,” and handed him a broom like a knighthood. He swept with fervor, then with rhythm, then with the calm of a person who had been given a repeatable action and was not going to let it go. When he saw the chalk cups he asked, “Do I draw one,” and Evan said, “If you ever draw one do it slow and small and say something nice while you’re doing it,” and Noah said, “Like what,” and Vee, walking by with a pair of scissors in her back pocket as if they’d grown there, said, “Like ‘I forgive you,’” and Noah took that word as if it were water.

That night, halfway through Act Two, the red fabric river did a new thing; it snagged on a splinter in the table no one had seen and would have torn if Marcus hadn’t moved his hand like a man who has once broken something sacred and vowed never to again. The audience did not know; they only heard the intake of breath from six onstage lungs and the little “tsk” from Sophie in the wings, and then they saw the river run, smooth as a long apology. Evan, from the booth, watched the near-ruin and had a thought he didn’t care for, that the show wanted to be something and would try with or without him, and then he had the better thought that his small interventions mattered because they made beauty possible instead of merely lucky. He pressed “Go” and felt his finger like a vote.

After, when the room had emptied of its borrowed heartbeats and the lobby smelled like damp coats and gratitude, Tess sent everyone home except him and Colm, which felt like being kept after school by a teacher who wants to ask you about your mother. She went to the prop table and placed her hands flat on either side of the red freckles and closed her eyes like a person listening for a train. “It’s quieter,” she said after a while, and then she looked at the chalk cups and added, “Don’t think I don’t see you dipping into the pantry without asking. If you make a mess you clean it.”

Colm grinned with his mouth closed like a boy, and Tess rolled her eyes and said, “You two are going to give me a heart attack and then you’ll add me to the lighting plot as if a ghost weren’t a nuisance,” and then she put her hand on Evan’s head briefly, the way Magda had done without the history, the way June had done with all of it. “You’re learning a new kind of flight,” she said, brisk so he wouldn’t get ideas, and then she was gone, the door swinging with her authority for a full minute.

The next day rain came in a uniform sheet like the town had ordered it from a catalog and was now obligated by return policy to keep it. The bridge swelled its sound to be heard over the regular shush, and the chalk at the pillar dissolved into scripts the water understood better than they did. Evan went with Colm anyway because there are rituals that call you even when they have been half-undone by weather, and they stood under the lip of concrete and listened to the sound of the river correcting itself. The red mark from two nights ago had been painted over by someone efficient, a gray bandaid on a bruise, and the new gray had already learned to be damp in a particular way. Colm did not draw anything. He stood and put his hand in his pocket and brought out nothing but lint, and he smiled at the river and said, “You’ll tell me if you’re unhappy,” and the river said what rivers say, which is Yes and No and Always and Never, a grammar of contradictions that nonetheless holds boats.

On Sunday June made a roast that had never met an animal, and Arthur pretended to carve it with ceremony and then passed plates like a man at a communion rail. They ate and did not talk about bridges or doors. They talked about a neighbor whose child had shaved his head for charity and about a man at the hardware store who had given June a discount as if she were a story he wanted to be in. Colm told them a tame version of an evening that had ended with him walking a drunk home and putting her on her own couch like a coat and leaving a glass of water on the piano where she’d see it. Evan told them that the hat had disappeared and been found on the hat rack as if it had finally decided to follow its own instructions. They were a family for a whole hour, with repetitions and interruptions and the knowledge that the week would rip them into their separate costumes again.

In the night, because nights will, it came back and tried another room. Not the bridge, not the theater, not the church basement with its coffee-stained democracy. It came to the bus that city workers parked behind the library, a long yellow animal that dozed on its own fumes. The driver arrived before dawn for one of those routes only birds and insomniacs notice and found a smear on the glass over the emergency exit in the back, a handprint incomplete and too small, the sort of mark that makes you think of children first and then of hands that don’t belong to children anymore. He called someone because he was a good man; the someone he called called someone else because that is how towns function; and the someone else who answered was Colm, because of course, and because the town had learned a number that woke him.

They went together in the gray butter of early morning, Evan and Colm, the streetlights not yet convinced there would be a day. The bus stood in its place like an animal chained to a post that only it could see. The mark looked almost pink in that light, absurdly sweet, and that made the back of Evan’s teeth ache more than red ever would. He walked around the bus with a hand out the way you walk around a sleeping horse and spoke to it without words because you do that when a thing is large and could harm you without malice. Colm climbed the stairs and stood in the aisle and put his hand on a seat, and the bus accepted his touch like metal does, all or nothing.

“Do you hear it,” Colm said, and Evan wanted to answer No on principle, but the truth was a small humiliating Yes because the idea had entered him and would not be evicted. It was not a sound, not exactly. It was a held note. It was a breath with nowhere to go. It was a plane in a holding pattern, circling, waiting for fog to lift. It was the hand he had seen on the windshield turned into intention and trapped. He looked at the emergency exit and saw how it would be to try to push it and find that there were rules about which way doors open, rules the door refused to explain.

Colm did not draw chalk because chalk is nothing on glass. He took the roll of tape from his pocket—gaff, not painter’s, because some materials carry their own gravity—and tore it into a small square and then another and another, and he made a cross of tape on the emergency exit release, a child’s salute to seriousness. “This is stupid,” Evan said, and Colm said, “Yes,” and then he said, “Sometimes stupid is a language a room understands,” and then he breathed on the glass to fog it like a magician refusing to be a liar and placed his hand flat over the small hand that had been there, and Evan saw for a second the ridiculous and unbearable tenderness of a man trying to tell glass not to be cruel.

They stood there too long for men who had jobs, and then they left because theater and hardware and the day insisted. In the booth, later, Evan said “Standby” with a voice that was more bass than it had been a week ago, and he saw that Vee had wrapped her fingers with tape without bleeding to earn it, and he watched Noah sweep as if a broom could erase history and replace it with a very clean floor. In a lull between scenes, Tess said from the back of the house, “We will do another piece in the fall,” as if announcing a weather pattern, “one about places that misbehave,” and everyone groaned because devising a piece is a small war, and then everyone nodded because there is nothing worse than being safe.

That night a man who had never set foot in a theater came and sat in the back and watched as if his life depended on it because maybe it did; afterward he came up the aisle and stood near the booth and raised a hand like someone asking a question in school. He said to Evan, “I used to fly,” and Evan had the urge to salute him without knowing from what or to what, and he said, “I am temporarily grounded,” and the man said, “Aren’t we all,” and then he laughed the laugh of men who have watched clouds from the wrong side and left while the lobby still felt like a lung.

Evan lay in bed later and looked at the ceiling that he knew intimately, every hairline crack like a line on a map he could trace with his finger when he couldn’t sleep. The house made its sounds, the small pings and groans that mean a structure is remembering what it is to be held up. He thought of chalk and tape and cup shapes and red fabric and doors with rules and bridges and buses. He thought of hands on glass and hands on levers and the way a stage breathes when the lights go out. He imagined, not fancifully but in the manner of a person making a list before a trip, a set of instructions for being a person that he could live with: drink water, stand where asked, draw small circles that mean welcome, say Hold when you have to, say Go when you must, keep your hand on the switch and do not flinch when the light comes.

In the morning the sun did its plain yellow work on the brick of the theater and the pillar of the bridge and the paintboard in the boy’s hand. The town stretched and decided again to be a town. There were donuts at the firehouse and dogs nosing at grass and old men standing with hands behind their backs conducting invisible orchestras. Colm came to the kitchen with a newspaper he didn’t read and a look he couldn’t help and said, “There’s a woman who lost a ring near the river and thinks she wants it,” and June said, “Tell her to come get a bracelet instead; I have a tin of them,” and Arthur said, “He will, and he will take her to see the bridge and not give her the ring when he finds it because it is the wrong ring,” and Colm said, “Correct,” and then looked at Evan like a man looking at a weather vane he had relied upon for years and asked, “You on headset,” and Evan nodded and said, “I am,” and that was both an answer and a vow.On the seventh morning since he put his bag down in the front hall and let June call it staying, the town woke smelling like cut grass and wet newspaper, and Colm said, “The ring woman is real and she is outside your mother’s house because the world is small when it wants to be.” He said it while standing at the sink drinking water like a man who has been reminded how mortal a throat is. June wiped her hands on a towel and arranged her mouth into the shape that meant she would approve of anyone who asked for help if they did it without superiority. Arthur made a noise that could have been skepticism or exactly the opposite, and Evan looked out the front window because he knew his part, which was always to look first and decide second.

She was there on the walk under the maple that always made more shade than made sense, a woman in a dress that tried hard not to be new and a cardigan with those satin ribbons at the neck that you never use. Her hair was pulled back the way nurses wear it in hospitals and actors on stage when they play nurses, and her eyes were the eyes of someone who had moved between aisles for too long, the grocery, the drugstore, the church, carrying lists like they were oaths. She held her hand at her sternum like something there needed holding. When June opened the door, the woman turned that held hand into a wave and then into a brace for the other hand, which had, Evan saw, a small band of nakedness where something had been.

“I’m sorry to come without phoning,” she said, and Evan wondered if she had ever in her life done anything without apologizing first to air and to doorways. “I am Elaine. I— Colm helped my neighbor with her furnace, and someone put my name on a scrap of paper that ended up in his pocket and now here we are.”

“We like scraps,” June said, ushering her into the house with a softness that had saved many a ragged person from thinking they were ragged. “We keep them in boxes and pretend we’ll make quilts. Sit. We’ll put coffee in you and if you want to talk about a ring I will not let Arthur get righteous about how things are lost on purpose.”

“I am righteous about very few things,” Arthur said, and then proved himself a liar by handing Elaine a cup of coffee as if he were conducting a ceremony. “Tell us where the river took it.”

Elaine smiled at that, small but real. “By the little bridge where the rocks sound like they’re making fun of you,” she said. “I was there after my shift because the sound was a way to not think. I took off my ring to put lotion on because my hands— well.” She held them out and they were hands that had been dry and scrubbed and wet and scrubbed and dry, the skin like paper that’s seen the rain and been ironed and seen the rain again. “I put it in my pocket and then I did not put it back on, and when I got home I had lotion and no ring and I retraced steps and I used my phone like a flashlight though that is not what it is and I went back in the morning and then it rained and now I am here.”

“Describe it,” Colm said, not impatient, just saving the room time later when the light would be different. “Not the metals, the feeling.”

She blinked at him and then did the tiny nod he always valued in people, the one that meant they could take a sideways question and answer it straight. “It fits,” she said, and then laughed at herself for the simplicity. “It was my mother’s and it fits. It isn’t more precious than that and it is. It has a chip you only see when you tilt it. It did not cost anything to anyone who keeps records.”

June said, “I have a tin of bracelets,” reflex because she couldn’t help offering substitutes, and Elaine smiled like someone being handed a coat while she stands in a dress she has promised to wear because it was bought for her.

They went because that is what you do when there is a ring and a river and a woman who has made herself small to come and ask. The road at that hour was indifferent to drama. The man who sprayed for weeds was dressed like a ghost of municipal business. High school kids pretending to jog practiced a choreography of disdain and hunger. The bridge looked like it always did, which is part of why it’s dangerous; you forget how many feet have crossed it wanting different things. The river whispered its long gossip.

Elaine stood with her hands at her sides like a child and said, “I stood here,” and you could see it, the spot stamped with her trying. Colm went down the bank like a man who knows how to use his ankle bones and who knows the result of not knowing. Evan followed and hated the way the damp tested the rubber edge of his shoe. He could feel his throat prepare a speech about iron and pennies and slurred sweetness and he stopped the speech with a different voice, his own low. He said, for himself, “Standby,” because it was ridiculous and also worked.

Colm didn’t bring chalk because chalk is silly here. He brought a magnet on a string which was sillier and which worked, sometimes. He dropped it in the shallow and pulled up bottle caps like coins from a fairy story that doesn’t pay well, then he went further down where the river made that anxious murmur at the culvert and tossed in the magnet where the current was a little greedy. “It has a chip,” he said, remembering, though the magnet didn’t care about chips. Evan watched the water over his foot flatten and fatten, flatten and fatten, like a breath he could pace. He could smell iron because he had brought iron odor with him in his head; the river only smelled like river.

“I can go in,” he heard himself say, surprising himself and the part of him that would have gone anywhere but in. He took off his shoes, which made June’s voice rise up in his brain with a warning about hooks and glass, and stepped into Ohio in June. The water went to his calves and then to his knees, and there was that quick ache you get and then the animal part of you adjusts and calls it fine. He moved his feet along like he was dancing with the bottom because putting them down hard would be stupid, and he put his hand in and the water looked at his hand like a cat looks at a stranger, dubious and finely attentive.

He found nothing but stone at first, nothing but the cold that has less to do with temperature and more to do with wear. He then found a thing that wasn’t stone, a small oval of glass from a bottle that had been memorized by the current until it forgot it had started life as a handle for liquor. He picked it up and thought how easy it is to mistake histories that have been polished long enough. He moved a little deeper and felt a slick of algae that told him he should not move that way again, and then he felt a thing that was a circle, and his breath did the wrong thing because circles and rings and throats are cousins. He closed his hand not around it but beside it and then coaxed, as if the object were a shy friend of a friend at a party. The ring slid against his skin and attempted to go back to the river because everything tries to go back if you let it, and he said out loud, foolish, “Hold,” and the ring rested against his fingers like a bird that pretends it chose you.

When he came up out of the water he had a small piece of metal and a trembling he did not hate. It was not gold. It was a crooked hoop of something that had been plated and then had surrendered. It was not Elaine’s. It was a ring the river had made from something else the river had eaten. He held it up and Elaine shook her head and smiled anyway.

“I will keep that one if you don’t,” she said. “For the day. And for the story that goes with the day. If mine is still there it is wanted where it is. If it isn’t, I’ll find out I can live without it.”

Colm bent his head and looked into the water like a man reading a book he suspects is lying. He walked a little and sat on his haunches and looked weirdly priestly doing it. He didn’t draw anything, not even with a stick, which made Evan feel better because drawing cups on river rock would have made him want to leave. He put his hand on a stone and then lifted his palm and there was a line of red under his skin that hadn’t been there before, the sort of line that might alarm someone who hadn’t been living inside metaphor for a week. Evan flinched and then did not, because the line was under, not on. He made his breath change shape. He looked at Elaine’s hands, at the way they had learned to be steady from being demanded of, and he thought of the fake blood in the tub and the way it had accepted a finger and been silly. He thought of the nosebleed and of pressing a compress with the back of his hand so he didn’t have to look straight at the thing his brain had decided to name. He thought of the math of small kindnesses and saw how it totaled larger than most catastrophes.

On the way back to the house Elaine sat in the back seat and spoke to the ring that was not hers like people speak to a plant they have stuck in the sun to see if it wants to live. She said, “You’ll be a story,” and the ring did not argue because it had no mouth. At the corner a boy on a skateboard did a shape with his board that looked like grammar failing and then recovering, and Evan laughed without thinking, which is always the better kind of laugh.

At the theater Tess handed him a new set of responsibilities as if she had ordered them from a catalog and they had arrived in a box slightly crushed. “We have a matinee for a school that believes it is doing a good thing for their children which is how they make sure the parents keep paying them,” she said. “It will be loud in the ways quiet people do loudness. The questions afterward will be awful and revealing. You will announce ‘Please turn off your devices’ and be listened to by none. Also, our dimmers have a cough; if they do that cough during the red fabric sequence, you will lie to them and say we mean it. You will be very convincing.”

He went into the booth and sat for a minute without touching anything because he had learned you can’t put your hands on every tool you love every hour; you have to let them be furniture half the day. The school filed in like a creature with many sneakers. The teacher voices made layers, sweet and authoritarian, and the building adjusted itself to hold their amount of expectation. He said, into a mic that made everyone sound like a radio they trusted, “Please turn off anything that will ring,” and half a dozen children put phones deeper into pockets like burying mice. Vee came up the stairs with a paper cup and set it by his right hand without looking at him because sometimes that is how kindness behaves. “Sip,” she said, and then, “If they ask you anything in the Q&A don’t tell them there’s fake blood in a tub because then we will have to mop questions instead of floors.”

He did the show and it came like it should, with a bump at the place where the projector had been sulking, and he pushed past it with his thumb like a man refusing to listen to a sulking friend. The children made a noise he liked when the red fabric moved, the combination of “Oh,” and “I could do that,” and “It had not occurred to me to desire this until this second,” which was essentially the reason to open any door. After, when the lights came to half and the children were given permission to make theater about themselves, a boy raised his hand and did not wait to be called on and asked, “Is it scary when it’s dark in here and you are the only one who knows where the lights are,” and Evan said into the mic, “Only in the way being in charge of a light switch is scary,” and the children laughed and then a girl in the back raised her hand very formally and asked, “What do you do if you make a mistake,” and he wanted to say, “You don’t,” but his mouth, which was learning to be honest in public, said, “You forgive yourself quickly so you can stop making it,” and the kids made that humming sound children make when they are deciding whether to let a sentence into their private arsenal.

His phone buzzed as the kids left, and he thought, Max, because Max had a knack for buzzing him when he was between tasks, but it was Fischer, the beard man who liked maps and had a picture of a Cessna like a diploma in his office. He stepped into the hallway where the emergency light made everyone look like a rehearsal version of themselves. “How’s your leave, Marlowe,” Fischer said, which could be anything from “Are you stealing the pens,” to “Are you dying.”

“It’s a list,” Evan said, because that was as accurate as anything. “I have a job where I say ‘Standby’ and ‘Go’ and ‘Hold’ but no one dies if I say them wrong.”

“I recommend it to everyone,” Fischer said, and his tone made you suspect he meant it. “I’m checking because we have to check, and because I put your name on a thing that says you talk to Dr. Leary on Tuesday, and it’s not optional if you want your seat back, and I thought, be kind, tell him before a machine does.”

“I’ll talk to him,” Evan said, and he swallowed the little noise his throat had been saving for doctors. “I’m working on a muscle.”

“Good,” Fischer said. “You can build a lot of muscle in one place and discover it helps somewhere else. Someone told me that once, I don’t remember who, probably my wife. If you need more leave you take it; if you want to sit on a jumpseat with old men and talk about whether landing on one engine in Cincinnati is classy or stupid, you call me. We’ll be here when you decide you can look at the glass without choking.”

“Thank you,” Evan said, and this time he meant it without any little darts of irony at the word. He put the phone back in his pocket and felt like someone on the bridge in the first days of spring: the river still cold and mean and hungry, but the light moving differently across it and a person upstream thinking of taking their shoes off.

That afternoon he found himself on the floor in the wing, holding a staple gun and a piece of muslin and swearing under his breath because he had put the staple where no staple should be. Sophie leaned over him with a look that was ninety percent pity and ten percent the joyful superiority of a woman with a toolkit. “Your thumb is going to get you,” she said, and a beat later it did, the staple skidding and the skin betraying him with the smallest slick. He saw it, he felt the small sting, he opened his mouth for the old air, and then he closed his mouth and decided to let the sting be loud and the sight be small. He pinched with his other hand and breathed out with a noise like someone pressing a banjo string for pitch. Vee appeared out of somewhere with the little box of silly Band-Aids they kept for exactly this, the ones with cartoon clouds and the ones with a line for your name which amused Tess every time. “I am not falling," he said, and Vee, without making a face that would make him hate her, said, “I know,” and put the cloud on his thumb as if she were doing a magic trick for a child she decided to like.

Noah swept like a person who had found a religion, and when he slumped on the stage with his broom lying across his shins like an instrument he would refuse to learn, Evan sat next to him and passed him a bottle of water like it was contraband. “You could teach sweeping,” he said, and Noah said, “You could teach talking into a microphone,” and Evan said, “I could teach saying ‘Hold’ to a room until the room does it,” and Noah said, “I need that,” and took a drink like he had understood the metaphor and made it literal to be safe.

They talked about paint and doors and the boy said, “I didn’t know you could ask a room to behave,” and Evan said, “Most rooms like to be asked,” and Noah nodded with that hungry face boys have when someone offers them an adult sentence with their name on it. When Noah went to the lobby to carry two heavy things that had been designed to look light, Evan looked at the chalk cups he had drawn and saw they had smudged into little moons, and he did not redraw them because there’s a time to redraw and a time to let a line go back into the air.

There were storms in the forecast and the sky made a half-hearted drama of it all afternoon, a darkening that never committed, a rumbling that made the high windows in the booth twitch two millimeters every twenty minutes. Evan took this weather like a quiz he had not studied for, kept his paper blank for a while, then wrote his name on it, then decided to stay. When the rain finally came, it came as if scolded into doing its job, an efficient discipline. The building liked rain; it had learned to be hugged by it. The light board arcs sounded different when the dust above them found water; the air took the ghost of a smell like someone had ironed a thousand shirts in the next room and the doors were left open on purpose. He pressed “Go” with dry fingers and considered the nights he had pressed “Go” with sweating ones and the way humans mistake that for courage.

When he got home, June had left a Tupperware marked with masking tape that said “Roast you can live with,” and a note that said, “Went to book club, do not let them make me read anything where all the women are mean to each other.” Arthur had underlined an article in the paper about the city council and left the page for Colm on the table with a highlighter as if he were training a parrot to speak. Colm came in late with a smell like rain on wool and sat without turning on the light. In the dark, with only the street’s offering making the edges of the room visible, he said, “The boy has good hands for doors,” as if announcing a grade on a report card. Evan said, “He wants to not make trouble,” and Colm said, “Nobody wants to make trouble. They want to be listened to without qualifying the listening. That is different,” and Evan did not disagree.

“Did you find the ring,” Colm asked after a minute, and Evan said, “I found a ring,” and that was sufficient because sometimes a ring is an answer and sometimes it is a place for a better question to sit. They sat with that for a while without messing it up by talking around it. The house made a shift sound like a person turning over in sleep on the other side of a wall. Evan ate a piece of roast standing up because no religion should be pure. He poured water and looked at the glass and tried to see if it wanted to be cruel; it looked like what it was, a thing that holds and is held.

On Monday the theater was a shopping list. Tess put assignments on the whiteboard that had been cleaned so much it had its own sky. “Postcards at the coffee places,” she wrote, then added, “but only where they like us,” and “fix the squeaky hinge on the second row because it’s starting to think it’s in the show,” and “teach Noah to run house lights by Friday or else,” with three exclamation points she would later deny. Evan went out with Vee to tape a flyer to a bulletin board that did not believe in tapes and watched as she argued with the cork until it admitted her pushpin. In the window of the haberdashery pretending to be necessary, a mannequin with no head wore a tie like a wound. Vee said, “My father used to wear those ties and have opinions about the shoes of men on television,” which was a bigger sentence than she usually let out in daylight, and he said, “My father used to forget I could see him,” which landed between them with a polite clink, like utensils on a placemat.

“Do you go to see him,” she said after they had both decided they would not comment on what they had said, and he said, “I go to the place he works because it’s in my town and because his sorry shape is part of the skyline. He shapes wood with insistence and I have to respect that. He told me boys don’t faint. He was wrong in a category larger than fainting. He had a cut once, on his hand, and he slapped me when I fell down, and I keep walking past that in my head like it’s a picture in a hall I don’t have time to see.”

“Doors you don’t want to open are still doors,” Vee said, not gently and not unkind, and he felt a little angry because she was not in his family and how dare she be right, and then he realized he was not angry at her at all but at the sentence for being clever and true at the same time.

That afternoon, in a little pocket of nothing between acts and rain, a woman stood in the lobby holding her purse the way people hold Bibles when they aren’t sure they believe. She had a face that had been careful for many years and had lately quit. She said to Evan, “My kid was the one who asked you about mistakes,” and he said, “Your kid is good at questions.” She said, “He told me you said you forgive yourself quickly so you can stop making it. He said it while he was trying to fix the faucet I have been yelling at for two months and it made me want to lie down on the floor and cry like one of those women in movies who always end up married again by the end. Do you really do that.”

“Sometimes I forgive and sometimes I perform forgiving and hope the rest catches up,” he said, which was more exposure than a lobby requires. “Sometimes I make the same mistakes because I like them. Sometimes I make new ones and praise myself for the variety.”

She laughed in that dangerous way where the next sound could be anything and said, “You’re very unhelpful in the way that makes me feel less alone,” and then she bought two tickets and left with a walk like someone who had remembered she is funny.

That night the town had a sound like cutlery being put away after a party that had not been a success. The red mark came back in dreams in a smaller size, on the glass of a bus and on the back door of the theater and on the countertop where June had left a note about milk. He woke and went to the kitchen and drank water and pressed his thumb to the little cloud Band-Aid until its adhesive reminded him of childish loyalty. He thought of tomorrow and the man with the beard and the office with the airplane picture and the particular kind of reporting he would have to do about himself. He had feared storms and learned to fly in them. Now he had learned to light a room so that storms could be theater. He would sit in a chair and say a word like “panic” and wait for the person across from him to nod like a priest who has seen stranger sins. He would say “bird” as if it were both an apology and a punchline. He would say “blood” on purpose in a sentence and feel the way the air handles the word differently depending on who had invited it, doctor or actor or man in a kitchen at night with his hand on a glass.

Tuesday was blue and efficient. The office where Dr. Leary worked refused to be anything other than a room, which somehow helped. There were magazines older than most of the people who would read them. The receptionist had hair in a clip that reminded him of a rib. When he sat with the man whose job it was to make pilots tell the truth, he thought of checklists and found himself relieved. “What brings you here,” the man said in that voice that is taught in the rooms where therapists renew their licenses, and Evan said, “Birds do not bring me here, but they are the excuse, and blood is not a storm but my body thought otherwise,” and the man said, “Good,” as if he adhered to the church of naming things. They talked about cockpit doors and door doors and about the smell of iron that may or may not exist, and the man did not tell him he was ridiculous and did not tell him he was brave and told him instead, “What your amygdala is doing makes sense; it lacks context; we give it context; you go back when your body quits tripping the alarm at the wrong party.”

He left the office feeling like he had been given homework he did not hate. He drove past the airport and did not go in because he did not want to test any spells, and because he wanted to keep the runway a promise and not a dare. He went to the theater, which had become, for all its cobbled charms and its leaks and its smell of ten years of caffeine, a sanctuary. Tess looked at him and did not ask. She handed him a roll of tape and said, “The broom closet is rebellious; domesticate it,” and he did, arranging mops like soldiers, a satisfaction so clean it made him want to change his name.

After the show that night they did notes with Tess doing her best impression of a mean person because everyone had done well and praise makes them lazy. “Sophie,” she said, “your shirt is noisier than your scene; don’t let cloth upstage your grief,” and “Marcus, the hat is not a character, put it when you put it and stop letting it flirt with the audience,” and “Vee, you are one sigh too many; keep one for later; trust me; you can always sell your sighs at the market,” and “Evan, your ‘Standby’ is perfect but you are touching the faders with your middle finger like a man in a French film; use your whole hand so they know you’re married to the job.” He nodded like a student and made his fingers obey and felt the small rush of having changed a habit problem-side down.

When they were almost out the door Noah came running in through the alley with a look on his face that made Evan want to block a doorway and make the room smaller and safer by the square foot. “There’s a—” Noah said, and then did not say it because he had learned about not letting nouns win. He made instead a shape with his hands like two things that had loved each other and then been separated. “At the bridge,” he said. “Someone put something in the cup and now the cup is — I don’t have the word.”

They went with their coats half on. The alley had the trash smell of a city that is too polite to admit it is a city. The bridge had the look of a patient being visited by too many people who claim to be relatives. The chalk cups, or what remained, had collected rain and dust and small kindnesses, and someone, because humans cannot resist a vessel, had put a pebble in one, and someone else had put a broken bottle cap in another, and someone, because youth is exuberant, had put a cigarette butt in the last. The pebbled one was fine, the cap one was a joke that didn’t hurt, and the cigarette had burned the chalk edge into a black scar like an eyelash too long and too close to the flame. Colm stood and looked at the small damage like a man who has to admit he forgot to put something out of reach. Evan crouched without wanting to and put his hand near the burn because the smell of it had the same joke as fake blood, it suggested one thing and was another, and he could take that right now.

Noah rocked on his heels like a child pretending not to need to pee. “Did I ruin it,” he said softly, and Evan understood the grammar of that question, the I means all of us, the it means the thing we made and the thing making us. “No,” he said, because in this case no was true. “We are practicing. We will forget where the chalk is and we will leave the tape in the wrong drawer and we will invite something in with our big red hands and then we will put cups in the right place and ask for the right kind of quiet.”

Colm wiped the ash with his sleeve and made a face because he adored his sleeve. He took out a rag like a conjurer not because he had hidden one but because he had prepared one and was now pleased by his own competence. He wiped until the black was a memory. He drew the cup again, smaller, in a place where a shoe would have to be rude to hit it. He said, very quietly and only once, “Stay,” and Evan watched his brother’s breath and saw how it matched the water and learned another thing about what he was really doing here.

On the seventh night since they began calling it a run, the audience contained a man with a scar through his eyebrow and a woman with a scarf that had traveled more than she had. June sat in the front row and held her hands in her lap the way she would if she were on a bus with a baby nobody knew where to look at. Arthur took notes in the dark with a pen that glowed, which made him look like he had been given a position by a deity. Colm stood for a long time and then sat when someone else wanted that space more. Evan pressed “Go” and he meant it. He said “Standby” and the word did not sound like a lie. He put the river and the ring and the chalk and the boy and the bus and the nose and the glass and the bridge in a place in his chest that was not a closet and not a trash bin; it was a shelf. He felt the shelf hold. He felt the shelf shudder and then settle. He put his hand on the fader and let his whole palm touch it like vows are supposed to be touched, with all available surface. The red moved like a language. The stage breathed like a thing that loves you when you do not deserve it and which will be there when you do.

After, he stood in the door on the side of the stage where the actors go out to smoke and make pronouncements and said to Noah, “You draw the cups tomorrow, if they need them,” and Noah said, “I will,” and then, as if offering information about the weather, “I told my mother I made a door by accident and she said she had made three on purpose and we laughed,” and Evan thought that maybe, if there were an after, this would be what earned them it.

Later, in bed, with the window open just enough to argue with June’s preferences, he dreamed, not of the cockpit or the stage, but of a room that had been both and neither, a room with bolts and light and the smell of warmed dust, a room where there was a switch and the switch had a label and the label was his name. He pressed it, in the dream, and nothing terrible happened and the room did what rooms do when you ask them with your whole hand. He woke to a morning that did not mind being itself and made coffee and went downstairs and said “Good morning” to the house the way he sometimes said “Hold” when no one was listening and meant it.He woke with the particular clarity that sometimes visits you after a week of being someone else and being yourself at the same time, a thin bright line down the inside of the day that made him think he could thread a needle without looking. June had left a bowl of apples on the table and the newspaper folded to the page Arthur would want to scold, and the light came in over the sink with that late-morning leniency that forgives any number of late nights. He poured coffee and let it be coffee without auditioning it for metaphor, because there are days when even men who like to name things permit nouns to be just nouns. When he looked up, Colm was already there in a chair like he had grown from it overnight, the warmth around him banked and thrifty, his hands around a mug as if he were cooperating with a ritual and not leading it. “Today is a day for errands,” Colm said, as if he had checked with the calendar personally, and June, who never believed in light work, said, “Errands are what life is made of,” and handed him a list with her handwriting marching, as if it had been trained in a tiny army where persuasion outranked force.

On the way to the Evergreen he detoured on purpose by the turnoff to the airport, the lanes blued with paint in numbers that will outlive the people who painted them. He did not pull in, because there is a difference between flirting and making trouble, but he let himself look at the sign until the shape of the word felt like a thing he could put in his mouth again without choking. Max texted him a picture of a weather radar with a little circle around a chunk like a bruise and a caption that said, “She’s ugly and leaving for Pittsburgh,” which was Max’s way of showing affection. He sent back a picture of the light board with faders standing like wheat and wrote, “She’s beautiful and doesn’t move without me,” and Max answered with fifteen thumbs-up that made him weirdly grateful for the stupid language of icons.

Tess met him at the door with a map of the day, which was her face. “We have a kindergarten at ten,” she said, moving a roll of tape from wrist to wrist like a bangle with obligations, “and they will ask better questions than the high schoolers and wipe their noses on our seating if we are not quick with the tissues. Then tech notes because we have gotten cocky and the lights got out of their lanes last night and I will not be made a liar by electricity. Then the mayor’s assistant would like to pretend we are a symbol and take a photo in which she will stand too close to a ladder and I will move her gently with my eyes. Also, someone put a handprint near the box office that is not in our paint palette. Bring your patience.”

The handprint was small and sincere in the wrong red, at the corner where people brush without noticing because bodies do that in buildings. It was not a horror film of a thing; it looked like a child had pressed curiosity to the wall, an experiment in, What will happen if I give away this much of my shape. He felt his stomach somehow step aside and make room for it, and the relief that came with that made his eyes prick, which annoyed him in the exact way relief will when it shows up in rooms you didn’t invite it to. “I have vinegar,” Vee said, already there, already wielding a rag with the authority of someone who had done this ritual on three continents in rooms with worse attitude. “I will charm it; you will not watch; Sophie will mutter about paint wearing thin and then fix it with a recipe she learned from a grandmother who taught her to knit and fight in the same hour.” He let them work, because masculinity had lain down in him for the morning and decided to nap, and because his function right then was to rehearse saying “Hold” to a room full of five-year-olds who would ignore him with more grace than most adults.

Kindergarten audiences are a religion if you let them be, and Tess had long ago become their liturgy. He said, “Half hour,” and got back a hundred versions of “What Is Half of Anything,” and then he said, “Five,” and watched a child near the aisle hold up a hand and count his fingers to make sense of being told to count at all. They watched the show with the kind of reverence children have for anything that looks like it requires adult permission, and then they made a sound at the red fabric that was neither gasp nor laugh but that little “oh” cats make when you open a new can. One boy asked if the fabric was a snake and if the snake would bite the bad guys, and Vee, who had unfolded herself into teacher for the duration, said, “There are no bad guys, only people who forgot what room they were supposed to be in,” and the boy looked satisfied, like the world had been returned to him in a condition he could hold.

After, a pale girl with hair like thread asked Evan into the mic, “Are you afraid when it is dark and your mom is not there,” and he said his mouth’s truth before his defenses could reassemble: “I am afraid and then I am not,” which turned out to be the exact dose she required. He gave her a flashlight and her teacher looked like she was going to cry and then didn’t, because you can tell a teacher by the way she treats her tears as capital to be spent wisely. Vee cleaned the handprint with vinegar and laughter and left a faint pink memory that couldn’t harm a soul, and Sophie blended paint while humming something you would not believe she knew, and for an hour the whole building behaved.

At noon Tess sent them to the coffee shop with a stack of postcards and the instruction to flirt with restraint, which Vee interpreted as a mandate to stare down a barista’s moustache until it agreed to put the cards in front instead of under the tip jar. The mayor’s assistant arrived as threatened in heels that were a joke on the idea of pavement and stood with Tess near the ladder for a photo that would be captioned with words about Community and Art and Partnership, none of which would include the price of gaff. “We love small businesses,” the assistant said, and Tess said, “We are smaller than you can be without falling through the grates,” and someone in the assistant’s brain wrote it down and labeled it folksy so it could be pulled out later at fundraisers to charm a crowd that pretended it couldn’t be charmed.

The power decided to be a character at two, in the middle of a cue-to-cue that Tess had insisted on because she liked to iron the same clothes three times if anyone was going to stare at them. There was a blip and a sound like an old radio pretending to die theatrically, and then the rich dark that has weight came up from the floor and sat in everyone’s lap. Someone said “Shit,” and someone said “Sorry,” and someone else tried to fix both with humor, which was the local currency. Evan’s body tried on an old habit, the one where dark is bad because dark is a prelude to alarms and glass and the smell of wrong; then his body remembered his other job, the one where dark is a garment they put on and take off with style. “Hold,” he said, not loud but full, and the room obeyed because it needed someone to tell it what to do with its new silence. He said, “House to half when she comes back and worklights on battery,” to no one in particular and to his hands, and Vee, who had a flashlight on her keychain because she is the sort of person who expects to be asked to fix things in rooms she doesn’t even like, snapped a beam down the aisle and made the darkness decide to be a hallway and not a swamp.

The audience of no audience behaved, sitting where they were as if they had paid for the right not to make a sound. The lights made their slow-tortoise return: the emergency strips first, then the green exit signs that suggest salvation and bureaucracy at once, and finally, grudgingly, the ghost light on its pole, which Evan loved in the way that children love talismans. He set up the board to come back online with the gentle hand a person uses on a friend who is pretending to be more fragile than it is, and when the dimmers coughed the cough Tess had predicted he coughed back, because petty machinery sometimes responds to mockery. “We will do that again,” Tess said to the universe after the room consented to be a stage, and the universe said, in its way, You will or I will.

The tub of stage blood is an object that will teach humility if you are arrogant and slapstick if you are not, and that afternoon it decided to make its case by leaping off a table as if bored. Marcus had moved too quickly, blessing of his character, and the lid had not snapped, and the tub did what tubs do when you leave them with no supervision—it took the floor for a brief red sermon. Someone made a sound with their mouth like an old car’s brakes and Vee started to swear in a language that did not exist and Evan’s eyes did their old trick, trying to pull the world in to one small spot, then his fingers saved him by putting gloves on before his head could be brave or cowardly. He knelt, and the ridiculous smell got there before the image, thank god—chocolate and corn syrup and the shame of convenience. He scooped and wiped and made the movement more important than the color and said out loud, like he was teaching his own hand a song, “It’s candy,” and felt the sweet destroy the iron in his head. Tess underlined the moment with a quip—“I told you I don’t believe in realism”—and Sophie brought a mop with the solemnity of a nurse, and slowly the floor was a floor again and not a metaphor audition.

In the late afternoon, when the time for catastrophes had expired for most normal buildings, Colm came in looking like a man who had made progress on a list and still had items that would eat him if he looked away too long. He had a smudge of something on the knuckle of his right hand that wasn’t dirt and wasn’t oil; if you asked, he would say it was from a lock that had decided to be poetic for an hour. He watched Evan from the back of house for a few minutes, in his way of measuring whether a person’s work had grown teeth or grown shy, then crooked a finger like a magician who has finally learned to ask before he pulls a coin from behind your ear. “There’s a place,” he said, because that was always how it began, “that used to be a bowling alley and is pretending now to be storage for a future that never arrived. Someone with spray cans and grief has been practicing there. Before it graduates to bridges again, we might ask it to study in private.”

The building was not far, because nothing in the town was ever far enough to be safe. It had been a place where people let balls go and waited for the world to make sense in ten neat explosions, a place of beer and shoes with other people’s ghosts in them, and now it held folded tables and optimism in boxes. The back door was the kind the town favored, metal with a rumor of rust and a bar like an instruction to the hand. Inside, light came through slats and dust in stripes, which would have made artists happy if artists hadn’t already found themselves something to be happier about. The lanes were there under a patchwork of carpet and plywood like old bones under a new skin, and the pins were gone except one, standing in the corner like a witness who knew it would not be called.

On the far wall someone had been practicing a language he or she did not speak. The red on concrete, in hand and palm and stroke and slither, was the work of someone who liked the feel of it, which is sixty percent of how trouble happens. Colm stood like a man at a museum, patient, letting the painting notice him before he noticed it in any useful way. Evan measured his breath against the room, felt the old crunchy lift of his chest and then the smarter slow. He carried in with him the theater’s softness—the way a person can move light like water and have it be consequence rather than command—and he set up the small work lights they had stuffed in the back of the car, clamping them to a beam the way you clamp feelings to the usable part of your day.

The light changed the red immediately, because light is rude and has no loyalty to anyone’s intention. The handprints that had tried to be solemn became affectionate, the streaks that wanted to be wounds cooled to something closer to crayon. “We’ll make a room,” Colm said, as if they were putting together the shelving unit of a god. “Then we’ll ask the room to remember itself.” He took out chalk, the cheap kind that does not pretend to be indelible, and Evan had the ridiculous thought that he should apply for reimbursement.

They drew the cups, not making prisons but making invitations, small, low, at the base of the shapes where the red wanted to drip if it were liquid, which it wasn’t. They didn’t draw over hands; they drew near them, a politeness learned from cleaning up after children and elderly men who still insist on cutting their own bagels. Noah arrived because he had been everywhere all day, vibrating at the edges and sending his willingness ahead of him like a dog that wants to be liked. He looked at the wall and then at Evan and then at the chalk with a face that had learned very quickly where not to put itself. “Do I,” he asked, and Evan said, “Yes, and say something nice,” and Noah, who had run out of profound two days ago and now had to let honest carry him, said, “Thank you for showing me what not to do,” and the lines settled.

They did not perform ritual because ritual is a trap when you don’t know the language. They did small things that had, if you were a certain kind of person, the shape of ritual at the edges. Colm breathed so that his breath matched the room, which is what he does when he is being the kind of ridiculous no one can teach, and Evan adjusted a light and felt his body do that clean, mechanical joy it does when a thing is correct before intention can put a signature on it. He realized the old ache in him had a rule he could exploit: if he could make his hands the most important part of what he was doing, his eyes would agree to be junior partners. “Stay,” Colm said to the wall and to whatever wanted to pull tricks on the edges of it, and then, after a beat in which no one was inconvenienced, he said, “Go,” very gently, like telling water it may return to being itself.

After, they walked around the building like nurses, checking windows and corners and the place where a back stair makes a decision about whether it is a place for secrets. A woman with keys came and thanked them with a thank-you card she had written before anyone made her grateful, the kind of faith that will always charm Colm and make him try not to say so out loud. She told them about the bowling league that had written its names on a napkin and lost them and then made do with calling each other “you,” and she laughed the small laugh of someone who doesn’t get to tell her stories in rooms where people are listening. He let her talk long enough for the room to register something besides red and chalk, and then they left, because if you stay too long after you close a door you start to doubt hinges.

Evan saw it then for the first time, the way the warmth around Colm dimmed and brightened like something with a battery. It would be funny if it weren’t so much like the cost of all things we love when we use them too hard. He said nothing, because love is occasionally smart, but the noticing changed him a degree or two, which is how loyalties grow up and become obligations you can keep happily. Back at the house June was making a cake that didn’t believe in sugar and insisted on being loved anyway, and Arthur was reading the paper out loud to someone not present, perhaps his younger self, and when Colm sat down he did it like a man who’d taken a long vow and brought it to completion for the day. “You look thinner around the edges,” Arthur said, which might have been a joke or might have been a mercy. Colm smiled with half of his face and stole a piece of the cake that had been set aside specifically so he could steal it, because this was a house that understood the theater of justice.

A letter came with the evening’s mail in a windowed envelope that would have been funny at any other time, and Evan took it outside and opened it on the porch because some sentences prefer weather. Fischer’s office and the company’s logo made a marriage up top as unromantic as any document, and the words under them were ordinary and devastating in a gentle way. They had put him on a simulator schedule eight days hence, on a morning when the sky would probably do its very best to mind itself, and they used words like “evaluation” and “readiness” and “support” that were either genuine or learned, which, in the end, feels the same if you’re the one trying to breathe. He stood with the paper and thought of the light board, of the way your thumb finds the switch without consulting you, the way your body sometimes makes decisions your mind can later claim as its own if it wants the credit. He thought of saying “Hold” into a headset and how nice it had been when a room listened. He thought of saying “Hold” to his own blood and having it proceed with its business anyway.

He told Tess because you tell the person you work with that something will change the way your mouth says “Go,” and she said, “Good,” with a plainness he valued. She did not congratulate him as if he’d won a thing; she put him into a list in which his absence would matter and did not act like that meant the list would end. “I will make Noah sit in your chair when you are gone,” she said, and Noah, in the doorway like a cat you forgot letting in, said, “I will sit, I will sit,” and then immediately assumed the posture of a person panicking quietly at being given a lever. Vee said nothing for a whole minute, and then she said, “If you leave, I get to use your pen and ruin the nib,” which was her way of admitting to feelings that would otherwise make her eyes too wet.

He told June because a mother is a form of air you have to keep honest, and she said, “They will be lucky to have your nerves again,” which would have sounded perverse if anyone else had said it. Arthur pointed at the envelope with a fork and said, “Coming and going is the work of men and trains; do it without drama and you will have done well,” which made June smack his wrist with a towel and say, “He is allowed drama at least until next Thursday,” and Arthur suffered the smacking like a man who has been punished better for worse.

The day before he was to go, the bus driver from the dawn and the glass came into the theater, hat in hand because that is how some men come into rooms with curtains. He watched from the back for a while, the way people do when they’re deciding whether a thing is a mirror or a window, and when Evan said “Standby,” the man’s shoulders made a shape, comprehension of ritual, recognition of power used for good. After the show he stood near the booth and said, “The tape stayed,” and Evan said, “Good,” which was both reply and sacrament. The man said, “I put my hand where the small hand had been, and for a minute I thought I was in church,” and then he left because he had a route and because some people will always speak one sentence longer than they think they are allowed and then go before anyone can be rude to the overage.

On the last night before the sim, Tess made them do notes after the house had gone home, even though everything had been fine enough to leave alone. “I do this so you don’t forget the world is bigger than the size of your accomplishments,” she said, which made Marcus groan theatrically and Sophie grin because authority wrapped in kindness is her favorite candy. She told Vee to pick a different shirt for the scene where she held the scissors because the current one insisted on finding light that didn’t want it. She told Noah to stop trying not to move the brush when he swept, because trying not to is a movement too and makes twice the work. She told Evan his voice on the mic had found a register people trust, and then she added, “Don’t keep it when you don’t need to, your friends will make fun of you for sounding like a god in a kitchen,” which made him promise not to order toast like a tyrant.

He didn’t sleep as badly as he’d planned. Fear does not always behave and sometimes chooses to be boring, which is a relief disguised as an insult. He woke with his lungs in his chest instead of near the door and made coffee and let June put a banana in his bag because potassium is a religion if she’s in the room. Colm drove him to the airport because he cannot not be the person who carries men to doors and waits near the hinge. They said almost nothing on the way, because men who like words know when to leave them in the house and let the day do the talking. At the curb, where men hug like they are making a trade in a marketplace where everything is a little too expensive, Colm squeezed his shoulder and said, “Whichever room you are in, you do not owe it blood,” which was more than a blessing and less than a curse, and then he let go because letting go is the only trick worth perfecting.

The simulator building is the opposite of theater in that it refuses to be romantic, which is its own kind of mercy. Fluorescent light is honest even when it is cruel, and the chairs have been sat on by men at their smallest and men at their bravest and do not care. Dr. Leary had sent him a link with breathing in four-square and a suggestion that he consider the bright idea of not losing six pounds of water through fear in an hour, and he took the suggestion and breathed as if someone had asked nicely and not because he wanted to impress anyone. The sim itself, the cockpit on stilts with a brain, was so close to familiar his fingers tried to skip the part where they asked permission, and he made them behave like guests at a good party.

The instructor had white eyebrows that made him look kind even when he was not sure he was being, and he said, “We’ll go where you take us,” which is an outrageous sentence in that room, and then he gave Evan the weather of his own week: clear enough but daring you to lie. He ran the checklist and let the list run him, which is how you do anything good. When it was time to lift, he lifted. When it was time to pretend to land because men in rooms with expensive machines love to be generous by inventing disaster, he pretended to land in a wind that had decided to tell jokes. When it was time to lose an engine and decide that one becomes two by a sort of math you can’t teach children, he found that old place that isn’t bravery, exactly, but the reliable result of training that has gone into your bones.

They did not spill fake coffee. They did not make the fake headlines. They did not look at a bird pretending to be a plane and have to renegotiate centuries. He saw red differently once, not from the window, but from the panel’s little lights, when an indicator for a thing that wasn’t a thing blipped and he felt his old alarm ring like a neighbor at a door they should not have a key to. He said “Hold,” under his breath, because he can’t stop being a small liturgy now, and then he said, “Go,” and the fake plane did as asked. When they were done, his shirt clung in a way that would embarrass you if you were seventeen and vain, and the eyebrow man said, without flourish, “You’ll live,” which might have been the highest praise any sacred room could give.

The lobby on the way out had a pot plant pretending to thrive and a bulletin board with notices for seminars no one would attend unless their licenses depended on them. He sat for a minute on a bench and let his body catch up with itself, then texted Tess a single word—“Go”—which she would read into whatever she had at hand. He texted Colm a picture of his shoes on industrial carpet and wrote, “I am where the room asks,” and Colm replied with a picture of chalk dust on his fingertips and wrote, “So am I.” He drove back to town with the odd feeling a person has when he has done the thing he feared he could not do and now must decide what to do with the part of him that was keeping fear as a pet.

The theater smelled like warmed dust and cut fruit when he walked in, and the light in the booth was doing that slow pulse the dimmers sometimes do when they think people will forgive them for having mood. Noah had written “Standby” on a sticky note and stuck it to the edge of the console because he is a poet even when he means to be mechanical. Vee looked at him and said, “You look like you met a man who was kind to you and you didn’t know what to do with it,” which is almost what had happened, and he said, “I pressed ‘Go’ in another room,” and she said, “Good, no one died,” and he said, “Correct, and I wore a shirt,” and she said, “Stop, we’re about to be friends and I haven’t decided if I can afford one.”

The show that night held him like it had missed him, which is something that buildings do not do but which, if you hold them in your mind just right, feels true. He said “Standby” and knew the word in two languages now, the language of switches and the language of breath, and both belonged to him in a way he didn’t have to argue for. The red fabric moved, and the audience, those strangers who are always cousins, made the noise that makes all the rest bearable, and he put his hand on the fader with his whole palm and let himself belong to the lever and the room without tithe or smear, without forgiveness demanded on credit from a future that owed him nothing.

After, in the alley with the rain finally good and earnest, Colm lit nothing and stood with his hands empty for once. “When a man learns to be two things he must not be surprised when he discovers a third,” he said lightly, then shrugged as if he had not meant to say any of it out loud. Evan laughed without cruelty and said, “Is the third a man who knows where we keep the extra gaff,” and Colm said, “It is also that,” and then leaned shoulder to shoulder the way he does when he is very tired and very proud of someone else, and they breathed in a rhythm the building under their feet approved of without saying so.
