The first time the blood spread across the glass like a long slow hand, Evan thought of paint. A smear of barn red, opaque, a child's bold brush dragged across the windshield of the Embraer that was taking sixteen people and their pretzels down toward Cleveland. He had time to think ridiculous things when the strobe picked out the feather-spit in the spray, when the lower leading edge of the wing shuddered from the bird they hadn't seen and couldn't have avoided. The hollow thud ran up his hands where they sat on the yoke. Besides, it wasn't his first strike, and he was supposed to be built for noise and weirdness and the sharp physics of sudden things.

"Bird," said Magda in the right seat, her voice fraudulent-calm, the kind they get as a faculty donation in year one of flight school.

"Yeah," he said, and then the hand on the glass became a slick, became drops, and he felt his heart run ahead of the plane, bolting.

He had flown with a little dread before. Everyone did. There was always the pinprick you hid, a thread hung from each flight that you refused to tug because the sweater of your head would unravel. His had been storms, always storms, anvils and green light, lightning that looked like a mouth opening. But this. This wasn't a storm. It wasn't even dangerous, not exactly. The alerts stayed quiet. The engine numbers were steady, though the left one took a breath he could feel through the floor. Not dangerous. Just red. Red and water and the idea of meat.

"Checklists," Magda said.

He blinked. It was there in his throat, the sweetness of it, the way you know a nosebleed is about to start, a metal penny somewhere in the back of your tongue. He nodded, but didn't reach for the laminated card. The card was right where it always was, in the slot, red triangles and cool font. His hand refused to go.

"Ev?" Magda said, softer.

"I've got it," he said, and the "it" felt like a lie. The drops began to crawl upward, slower now because their forward momentum had decreased. He watched one in the perimeter of his vision move in a long lazy comma.

He knew enough to know his own body. The tremor in his forearms. The way air got stuck behind his sternum like he'd swallowed a cough that was too big. Stupid. You could fly through ice. You could arc around storms in the purple black night with lightning ahead making sculptures out of clouds, silhouettes of Greek gods and teeth. You could make decisions at two hundred knots. So, fine, move your hand. He stared at the card until the ink turned into tiny printed islands. Move your hand, Evan.

Magda's hand landed on his wrist like a perching bird, light, a warning that could be read any way you wanted. "Breathe," she said, and the pity in it made something shameful twinge in his belly. "Breathe, and start the list."

He inhaled. The cabin was pressurized and dry and smelled faintly of coffee and hydraulic dust. The blood, which he could not exactly smell, had nevertheless colonized his head with its idea. Fine. Breathe in, breathe out. He told his hand to leave his lap. The hand didn't. The hand had declared sovereignty, a republic of skin.

"Checklist: bird strike, suspected," Magda said, and took the card herself. Her voice had become hands, making the words into useful items. He answered where he needed to, because you didn't forget the catechism. Halfway through, the droplets had formed a rake of red across the glass. He could see the runway through it, horizontal lights, the clean line of it, the wetness of the day out there. He focused on that, on the over-run lights like things you could walk on. He would centerline this thing, he would taxi it, he would sign paperwork and then he would go to the closet in the crashpad and he would sleep with his head under the coat that smelled like rain.

They landed. Everyone applauded, because everyone always did on these little runs, and he tried to feel the old soft irony of that, or the old soft fondness. He felt nothing except for an almost empty relief, like the feeling right after you've almost fallen down the stairs. Magda's hand was again a bird. "You're white," she said. "Like... extra white."

"I'm fine," he said, and he couldn't tell if it was true.

The captain of maintenance met them at the gate with a bucket and that fake brightness that ground guys sometimes have when they know the pilots think they're the help. "Gonna need you to fill out—"

"I know," Evan said, but it came out a whisper.

"You okay, Marlowe?" the man said, and he meant it, but he also meant Am I going to have to call anyone.

"Fine," Evan said. He didn't look at the windshield. He didn't look at the rag in the man's hands with the rust on it. He didn't look at the smear. When they got the debrief in the small room with the bad chair and the black coffee, he held the styrofoam cup like a charm. He thought, idiot, birds hit planes. This isn't a story. This is Tuesday.

He went back out into the chill slick of the jetway when all was said and done and the passengers had gone and the jet was quiet, and he put his hand on the fuselage. It felt like tapping a sleeping animal. He loved it. He felt something like love anyway, a memory of it. He had the absurd thought that his love should be stronger than a smear on a windshield, that love of a thing should toughen you, like callus or scar.

"Hey," Magda said again, as if perhaps he had gone somewhere. "Hey. You're shaking."

"It's cold," he lied, and walked as if he were not walking.

Later, in the crew room, he took a breath and caught sight of a news clip on the television overhead: a house burned in Chicago, the camera loving the curl of black and orange, and then an old man with a bandage crooked on his head, red moisture leeching through the gauze. For a second he thought he would vomit.

He put an arm against the wall. He didn't, because he'd learned long ago how not to do things. He went to the locker and took his bag and he went to the bus to the parking lot, and he drove to his crashpad through Columbus twilight, and the trees were black cut-outs and everything felt like it had been recorded, like he was playing back a thing that had already happened.

At the crashpad, Max from dispatch sat on his couch with a beer and a video game. He grunted. "You look like someone shot you with flour."

"Bird," Evan said.

Max laughed. "Hate those stupid feather missiles. You good?"

"Yeah," Evan said. He showered with the water too hot, as if he could scald the day away, and thought, this is very dramatic, isn't it, Marlowe. He brushed his teeth and saw toothpaste like foam like something else and swore and turned away. He slept for three hours and woke with his heart scudding in his chest, like a horse in a small barn.

Two days later, on the tarmac in Detroit, he watched a ramp guy trip, land on his palms, and nick his chin. The cut was mean, a tiny quiver in the man's face and then a line, a line that in the cold wind beaded. Evan felt the world go at an angle. A ramp guy. A nick. He went down on his heels by the tug, his breath loud in his ears like he was listening to a shell.

You can't fly like this, he thought, as if someone else had said it to him. You can't.

His chief pilot, a man named Fischer with a neat beard and the chill composure of someone who likes maps, called him into the office after the Thursday commuter flights had been farmed out to other souls with other bags under their eyes. The office had a picture of a Cessna framed like a diploma.

"You want me to guess?" Fischer said.

"It's... I don't know," Evan said. "I'm off. I think I'm catching some kind of—"

"Not sick," Fischer said, like he'd already set the suspects in a line and shot them. "You're white as a paper cup. And Burke told me you had to sit down in Detroit because you saw a little blood."

It's amazing, how quickly it spreads, he thought. Words. Like weather off a lake.

"It's not like I'm going to faint," he said, though once, twelve years old in a school gym when a girl fell off the pyramid in cheerleading and hit her eyebrow on the floor, the red made the world go velvet and he put his head between his knees like the gym teacher said, and the floor smelled like sneakers and wood polish and something sweet.

"Listen to me," Fischer said, folding his hands so you knew he thought it was important. "I know men who can't fly in November because the sunlight at four o'clock makes them cry. I know a lady who has to count to two hundred before she pushes up the thrust levers. We used to take people like that out back behind the hangar and tell them to get their heads right. I am not that guy and this isn't that airline. If you're telling me you got a problem with blood, you get to go talk to somebody, and you don't get to fly until somebody says you're good."

"I didn't sign up for sick leave."

"Then take unpaid," Fischer said, not unkindly. "You want to kill sixteen strangers because a passenger has a nosebleed in Row 9?"

Evan thought of the bird becoming smear becoming hand. He thought of the idea of blood behind the sight of blood, the entire architecture of what it meant. He had always thought he didn't fear mortal things, that his fear was shapeless, fog-like. Now, suddenly: a shape.

"I'll go home," he said.

"You got family?"

"In Westerville," he said. "Yeah."

"Good," Fischer said. "Go let them make casseroles. When you come back, we'll still be here."

He didn't feel very casserole. He put his bag in the trunk of the old Mazda he kept in the employee lot because it was paid off and because he had never liked anything that looked expensive. He drove north on 71 until it softened into the Columbus belt, then off into the map he could draw with his eyes closed: the older trees, the weirdly wide streets, the old brick that someone had deliberately left old, the town that had reinvented itself from old new, from Methodist to microbrew without quite forgetting either.

Westerville had a particular quiet to it in summer, like bees in your head. He could hear it as he turned onto State, the storefronts with letters that were trying too hard, the woman he recognized even if he didn't know her name walking a dog with a sweater like a golf club. He stopped in front of his mother's house even though he had not called. The porch boards sang hello under his feet as they had sung when he was nine and twelve and nineteen and left without telling anyone for Indianapolis because he had gotten a job washing airplanes and you didn't announce that you were going to become someone else.

June opened the door even before he knocked. She had a sixth sense for her child, or that was what she said, and also she never took off that necklace with the shell button and the tiny sliver of sea glass, and it made a small sound against the door, a clink like a teaspoon. She wore a sleeveless blouse that showed the freckle on her shoulder he had memorized as a toddler. Her eyes flicked from his face to his bag to his face again in a flash so quick you could almost miss the calculation.

"Are you in trouble?" she said, but with love; in their family "trouble" could be anything from a breakup to death.

"Only the usual," he said, and tried to make his mouth look like a joke. She hugged him anyway, the way she hugged, fully, like she was taller than she was, like he could disappear if she didn't do it whole. He felt briefly like a little boy back under the canopy of her life.

"You smell like airport," she said into his collar. "Come in, make that go away."

The house was saturated with her. Plants that were always about to die but never did. A rug his grandmother had braided, the edges slightly upturned like it was smiling. In the kitchen, Arthur sat at the table with a newspaper and his careful glasses. Arthur wore glasses like a man who had practiced them. Everything about him was careful, though he worked with wood and sometimes got splinters. He raised a hand. He wasn't mean. He wasn't kind either. He was a good stepfather at a distance, which was better than a bad one up close.

"You hear?" Arthur said, and did not explain what "you" or "hear" were supposed to mean. He had that voice of men who assume you live in the same head.

"I heard birds," Evan said, and Arthur snorted in a way that could have been either affectionate or not.

"Your mother marked the calendar when it's squirrels at the feeder. If I had to mark birds on glass I'd run out of ink."

"Arthur," June said. "Be gentle."

"I'm not being not gentle. I'm being factual," he said, which was how you knew he wasn't just being factual.

"It's nothing," Evan said. "I'm taking some leave."

She gave him that look, a twin of Magda's, the same species of human creature who had told you to breathe when you forgot. "And you came home."

"I've got other places, but none of them have a porch," he said. "Besides, the rent's paid to the landlord of Mom. You can't beat the rate."

"You can always beat the rate if you tell me with enough notice to put a roast in," she said, but she brought him a beer that wasn't craft and didn't care. "Do you want me to call Colm? He was here yesterday for lunch like a thunderstorm."

There it was, the other ghost in the house. The stepbrother whose name could change the temperature in a room. Not because of any fault; because of presence. Colm had a presence like a mantelpiece you didn't choose but someone had bolted above your fireplace. It was stately, beautiful, annoying. He had come with Arthur ten years before and had adapted to the house like ivy, soft and covering and unstoppable.

"It is a weekday," Evan said. "Doesn't he... do something at night?"

"Who can tell," Arthur said into his coffee. "He calls it work. He comes home with money and stories that can't be true. There's a smell like a candle when he's done, and your mother puts out bread on the counter because she thinks he hasn't eaten."

"I don't," June said.

"You do," Arthur said, "but I don't hold it against you. That's what mothers do with creatures who look hungry. They feed them until they stop howling."

"Don't scare him," she said. She turned back to Evan. "Do you want me to call?"

He hesitated, and the hesitation had layers. Colm and he had never been one thing. They had been a series of small treaties built and broken and built again. Colm was older by three years but younger in ways that made him dangerous to himself and others. He had a laugh like a match being struck. He had a way of standing in a doorway so that you knew you were in the room and not in the world. He also knew everybody in Westerville who thought they were somebody and most of the people who were truly somebody and didn't look it. If there was a party, he could get in the back door of it. If there was a problem, he could find the ditch it had gotten stuck in and pull.

"Sure," Evan said. "I could use a—" What? A wing no, don't say that. A break. A job? "A distraction."

June nodded and went to the wall where the phone numbers were still written on paper because she didn't trust the small glass rectangle where everything else lived. Evan went to the back door and watched rain starting to form on the maple leaves. The sky had low clouds like a ceiling that needed repainting. He felt weirdly relieved to be in a place where skies were just skies.

He told himself he had always known how to sit with things, but the truth was he had always moved. He had been a mover since he was old enough to imagine motion. As a child he ran in circles around the coffee table until his mother made him stop not because of furniture but because the circle inside his legs scared her. The first time he saw a cockpit, he had the feeling some people have when they step into a church that is older than their language. He belonged. He'd learned to belong in that small room with a thousand levers, and to pretend the rest of his life was an annex to that room.

"He's coming," June said, too fast, like if she said it slow she would be admitting something. "He says he was coming anyway."

"He always says that," Arthur said.

"So do you," she told him, and he shrugged.

Colm arrived like he had a key to the house he didn't; the door opened and he walked in on June's "come in!" like a rumor that had decided to become a man. He had that thing where he looked different each time. Today he looked like he'd been to a place where money went to get old, a thrift store where the good suits ended up. His jacket was soft and small at the shoulder, a little too tight, and his shoes were not quite brown or black. He smelled faintly like something hot. It wasn't cologne, exactly. It was like someone had put cinnamon through and then opened a window.

"Brother," he said, and it was the word itself that got you, the way he said it with gratitude as if the world owed him nothing and then gave him this boy to be brother to and he was going to say thank you for the rest of his life. "You look like you got introduced to winter and told to shake hands."

"I'm fine," Evan said, default setting.

"You're not," Colm said, delighting. He hugged him and Evan stiffened because he always did. It wasn't dislike. It was the way Colm really hugged, with everything, squeezing the air out of your bones like he was checking for coins. Colm stepped back and tilted his head at the way birds do when they see something shiny. "You get beat up by a bird?" he said.

"Sort of," Evan said.

"He got beat up by the idea of a bird," Arthur muttered, because Arthur couldn't stop saying what he thought, truly couldn't, it distressed him not to.

"So you want an idea of a drink or the real thing?" Colm said. His eyes, which at rest were brown, caught a light that made them look molten sometimes, like they held a little fire. "There's a place, and there's a person at the place, and the person thinks I am a person who knows other people."

"My big dream," Evan said. "To be a person who knows a person."

"You joke," Colm said. He always took jokes personally because to him everything was a gift you could unwrap, and if you didn't unwrap it he couldn't tell whether you liked him. "But it's a thing. The person is at the Evergreen. They do shows. They are not, you know, Broadway with the chorus lines. But they are... something. And they have a thing that needs a voice and a hand and maybe somebody who can read a map."

"Theater," Arthur said, as if the word were a lost relative.

"Theater," Colm said. He rolled the word in his mouth. "I told them I knew a man who can talk a pilot into landing in a hurricane, and who can make a room like a cockpit, calm. Fine, not a hurricane. A storm that no one else will fly. I said you had a voice like a switch warming up."

"You're selling me like a table saw," Evan said.

"Yes," Colm said, unabashed. "But it's for good."

"What's the job?" June asked, as if she were not going to approve either way.

"There is a show," Colm said. "They call it a devised piece. That's arts talk for we are going to do a thing that isn't a musical and it isn't a play and it isn't the news. They want someone to narrate it and someone to do the—" He made a gesture with his hand that could have been puppets or lights or pressing an elevator button. "—the cues, the buttons. The person who does that had a baby and then found out she liked having a baby more than having a job. Imagine."

"They want a stage manager," June translated.

"Is that a thing?" Colm said. "Then yes."

"I can barely manage myself," Evan said.

"Which is why you're perfect. You need to be better at it. They will boss you. They will be short of funds. They will give you drink tickets and pretend it is money. You will look at girls who pretend they don't look at anyone, and they will look back. And you will not be in the sky, which, from what I've heard, is your current prescription."

"He's not not in the sky because he doesn't want it," Arthur said. "He's on leave."

"I'm not a patient," Evan said, though it occurred to him that people who said that usually were.

Colm leaned against the doorframe, a habit of his that looked casual and felt like strategy, because now he was between you and leaving. "It's not for always," he said, softer, the sell now a whisper. "It's for a while. And you'll be around. And I can lend you my bicycle—"

"I have a car."

"I don't know that about you," Colm said, and he didn't smile; his face was sincere in a way that made you want to either confess something or pretend to be braver. "I know you fly. And I know—" he paused, not for drama (though he loved drama) but for honesty— "that sometimes, when I walk past the wall where she puts the pictures, your picture looks like you want to run. This isn't running. This is standing in a room and making sure it becomes something. Try it."

"Don't push him," June said, which, coming from her to Colm, sounded like a prayer you say because your heart is full and you don't like what comes out when it's overfull.

"I'm not pushing," Colm said. "I'm pointing. I'm a great pointer. Everyone says so."

"You've met two people today," Arthur said. "The barista and my wife."

"And the third person is the person I know who needs a person," Colm said, still smiling. He moved away from the doorframe, gave back the way out. "You can say no. You can tell me to walk out and I'll walk out. And then I'll walk one more block and lean into the alley and call Tess and say I tried. And she'll say, what do you want me to do, I need someone for tonight's tech run, it's not like someone is going to fall out of the sky."

At that, something in Evan made a bitter noise, a laugh that wasn't a laugh. "I know," he said. His mouth did what it always did: it decided before he did. "I'll go."

"You'll go," Colm repeated, as if that had been his prayer. "Good. Tonight?"

June made a face, which women have made since there were sons. "He just got in."

"I'll sleep later," Evan said. "If I sleep now I'll dream I'm in the plane and the glass is—" He stopped, because he had never said it out loud, and because saying it made it less and more at the same time.

They went out into evening. It wasn't quite rain; it was the weather where drops are arranged so far apart that each one feels lonely. Colm drove because of course he did, because he always took wheels like they were a throne. The car hummed like it had eaten too much honey. The radio played a station that played old songs by women who sounded like they had unscrewed their throats and let the gods sing through. The town slid past—the ice cream place with the kid in a sweatshirt though it was June, the library with its windows lit, the fountain that had always reminded Evan of an upside-down chandelier.

"You okay?" Colm said, as if he'd waited the appropriate number of minutes to ask, the number printed in an invisible manual he kept in his chest.

"Yeah," Evan lied, and then didn't. "No. It's stupid."

"It never is."

"I'm a pilot," Evan said, and heard how untrue that sounded. "I don't get to do this. I don't get to—" He gestured with a hand that made the turn signal click. "—be undone by a thing that wouldn't scare a student nurse. The world is full of blood. It's in us right now. I'm fine with it in me. I'm not fine with it on the outside of glass. I've been fine. Now I'm not."

Colm was quiet, which was rare enough that Evan looked at him. His face had gone profile, an old coin. He looked older when he was quiet. "When I was ten," Colm said, "my father cut his hand on a lathe. Not your father. Mine."

"I know which one you mean," Evan said.

"You didn't then," Colm said, not gently but not cruel, either. "He was alone in the shop because that was the curse he chose, to always be alone with the things he loved more than us. He called me in because he couldn't find the towel we used for oil. I saw the inside of his hand. There are so many pieces, and they were all living. I fainted. And when I woke up he slapped me. Not because he was cruel. Because he was angry I had done something he did not expect. He said, don't ever drop out like that. Don't ever. And I've been trying to never ever since."

"How's it working out?"

Colm smiled. "Depends who you ask."

The Evergreen Theatre looked like somewhere you took first dates because it would make you look smarter than you were. The door was painted green in case you didn't get the metaphor, and there was a flyer for a show with hands on it, so many hands, all the hands making a circle. The lobby smelled like coffee and carpet and ambition. A woman in her forties with the saving grace of a crooked nose came down the stairs with her arms full of papers. Her hair was short and gray like she had dared herself to go gray and had won. She carried herself like a person who could say "no" and make you grateful.

"This is him," Colm said, like he'd brought her a cat and was hoping she didn't have allergies. "Evan. The one I told you about."

"Tess," she said, untucking a hand. "Bless you, because I am not above blessing. We're bleeding man-hours."

Evan's stomach twanged at the word bleeding, a string plucked. He made his face into a guy face, a here to help face. "Happy to help."

"You any good with light boards?" she said, not waiting for the niceties because niceties had been chased out by need.

"What's a light board," he said, honest.

"Good," she said, not missing. "You'll do what I tell you. Tonight is spacing and cues. Tomorrow is paper tech. Friday we let them think it's a show. There's a script somewhere but we're pretending we don't need it. Got it?"

"Got it," he said.

"And you," she said to Colm, "can go home, because I'm not paying for extra eyes."

"You never do," he said, and then leaned to kiss her cheek, a gesture so old and gentle it made Evan think they'd known each other longer than the theater had been a theater. "Don't burn him," he said.

"Me? Burn?" she said with a snort. "The place burns. I just put signs on the exits."

Colm was already halfway to the door. He looked back once, a habit as old as trains, and his look said what he always said when he was leaving you anywhere: you can do this. It was theatrical and real.

Evan followed Tess into the black box that was actually only partly black and more of a charcoal that held light like water. The stage was a flat plane with tape lines in colors that looked like confetti to him. The seats were steep, telling him that whoever sat here had to agree to be sat upon. On the back wall, a faded painted tree suggested that once, not long ago, they'd pretended to be in a park.

"You're late," said a girl whose job it had been, apparently, to tell someone this no matter the hour.

"He is not late, he's new," Tess said. "There's a difference, and the difference is that 'late' suggests fault and 'new' suggests hope."

"I like her," the girl said, and did not even look at him. "Hi. I'm Vee."

She looked like a person whose face had been designed by someone with a fondness for lines. She had lines around her mouth from smiling and lines on her forehead from other things, and a haircut like she didn't want to be asked about it. Her eyes were clever, which you couldn't say about everyone because not everyone had eyes that had been taught at school. "Do you know where the subwoofer is?" she said to him.

"In my car," he said, and that at least made her face change.

"Okay, he's funny," Vee said to Tess. "We keep him."

"He's here because we lost Sheila," Tess said to the cluster of actors in sweats and scarves. "Not lost lost, just baby lost. This is Evan. He is going to shut things up and turn things on and tell you when to do things."

"You could just call that God," said a tall man who had shaved his head and then put a hat on it.

"You can call it whatever makes you feel special," Tess said. "Places for spacing. Evan: booth."

He learned on the job because there was no other way. The light board was a land of buttons that were numbered and then numbered again in case you were blind. Tess told him that faders were friends. He put his fingers on them and something soothed in him because a small part of him had loved buttons his whole life. He had always loved the command that was not command, the way a lever makes a wall of light appear and you can pretend you did that, like a god with good software.

"Blackout," Tess said.

"Blackout," he said, and drew the fader down until the world became night. His stomach unspooled. There was something here he could love possibly, something like the way sky happens in pieces.

They ran the tech, which meant they did not act exactly, but moved the things you would later assume had been always in the right place. He watched, he obeyed, he pressed "Go" on the board when Tess said "Go," and it felt like flying in that he was not the thing but he was adjacent to the thing. He watched Vee and the tall man with the hat and a girl with a voice like a spoon tap and a man who moved like he hadn't decided if he was a dancer or a tree. They called the piece "Rend," which made Evan remember the smear on the windshield and he told himself he did not have to be triggered by nouns.

At break, he went down to the stage to coil a cable like they taught you, which is to say you did it right or it would kink and kick like a snake. Vee watched him. "You did that like you've done it before."

"I coil things in my sleep," he said.

She tilted her head. "What were you before you were a stage manager for an hour?"

"Pilot," he said, and waited for the inevitable "cool."

She said "Oh," but not like that. "So why are you... here."

"Leave," he said; it was the word that had become his answer.

"Did you break something?"

"My brain," he said, somewhat obscenely proud. "It's on recall."

"Good," she said, and he blinked. "Better now than after. Are you going back?"

"Dunno," he said, and meant the lack of knowing like it was a faith he was trying on, like a ridiculous hat.

She nodded like someone who had decided not to care too much for a week or a year. "You should drink water," she said, practical. "There's a jug in the green room. It tastes like cucumbers because Sophie thinks that's hydration."

He drank cucumber water. He watched actors take tiny bites of apples like they were feeding birds out of their own hands. He watched Tess not look at a list and then know everything. He pressed the "Go" button when told. The night began to feel like a machine with a rhythm. He watched his body not flinch when someone said "blood" in a line about families. He watched himself not be smaller than he had been in the office with Fischer. He watched himself imagine a future that wasn't a cliff.

At the end of the night, Tess did the thing she probably did every night of her life: she stood on the stage, pretended not to be sentimental, and said, "Good work, tomorrow eight," and then she turned to Evan. "We pay with checks because the computer hates me. They will bounce if I sign them. So you're paid on Wednesdays and we give you drink tickets for the bar because it's easier."

"Thank you," he said, and meant, thank you for making a way for me to be in a room.

Vee came up to him at the door and said, "You're better when you don't think," and he almost said, "my whole life will be that sentence," but he didn't, because he thought she would get it so hard it would hurt.

Outside, the town had decided to be night. The street was an illustration drawn by a child who had learned perspective yesterday. Colm leaned against the green door, his hands in his pockets because he thought pockets were a personality. He looked wrong for the street and also like the street had shifted to suit him.

"You waited," Evan said, surprised in exactly the way you shouldn't be if you knew Colm.

"Of course," Colm said. "He was good?"

"He pressed buttons with reverence," Tess said from behind him, putting key in lock. "Which is more than I get from my own spine most days. Thank you for the delivery. Pick him up tomorrow? Or does the boy drive himself?"

"I can walk," Evan said, though he would not, not because he was lazy, but because he had learned to be driven.

"I will pick him up and feed him something the color of wood," Colm said.

"I don't need to be fed," Evan said.

"You always do," Colm said, and there was that other thing in his voice, the thing that came in when it wanted to: authority. Not the authority of a man who knows, but of a thing older than a man. It passed like a cloud. Evan told himself he had imagined it. He told himself that ten times.

Back at the house, June had left a light on like a lighthouse and a note on the fridge that said in her saintly half-cursive: Turkey soup, no actual turkey. He warmed it in a pot because she did not trust microwaves and had told them since they were kids that buttons in the kitchen would make them sterile. He ate it and tasted salt and something under it like thyme. He thought, I am okay in this hour.

He slept in his old room with the window that had always known a small draft. He dreamed—not of glass and birds, which would have been too obvious—but of a theater with no walls and a voice like his mother's saying "places" and Colm's laughter like the sound a match makes. He woke once with his throat locked, the way it locked when he saw red. He went to the kitchen. The light under the microwave clock was green like a feeling you could make disappear with your fist.

When he turned around, he saw himself reflected in the window over the sink: his own face, older than it should be at thirty-three; the street light doing a halo it had no right to. And behind him, in the next room where the house held its darkness like a hand holds an egg, a suggestion of someone standing, tall, patient.

He turned yes, because he was not a coward even if he was.

The room was empty. Of course it was. It was a house at midnight in a town that liked to pretend there were more things in it than there were. He drank water. He went back to bed and slept like he was falling through a cloud and finding ground and falling again.

Morning came like a song he had half-remembered, the way morning comes when you are in a house that knows you and will forgive your noises. June put coffee in him like a legal drug. Arthur argued with the paper because the paper had opinions. Colm arrived with a bag from a bakery that made cinnamon rolls the size of helmets. He flung the bag on the table like a man throwing gauntlets. "Eat, or the gods will be angry," he said.

"What gods," Arthur said.

"Mine," Colm said. He smiled at Evan over the pastry. "Ready for day two?"

"I'm ready to keep my hand moving when someone says 'go,'" Evan said.

"Look at you, a joiner," Colm said with delight. "I never thought I'd see the day."

"You never saw any of the days," June said in that way that was light except for the half of it that wasn't.

They went again to the Evergreen, and again he pressed buttons and coiled cables and tried not to think of himself as a man who had flown but couldn't stand the sight of a finger nick. He watched Vee make herself into someone else and then into herself again. He watched Tess take a call in the corner and say, "Yes, but no," and then say, "Fine," and then say, "We'll make it work," three times. He learned more than he had thought he would. He stood behind the light board in the utter dark and felt powerful and small.

At break, he stepped outside into an alley that smelled like summer and trash that had not yet decided what it wanted to be. He leaned against the brick. He looked up and let himself look at the slice of sky he could get. It was ordinary day-blue. It did not make his heart run. A pigeon flopped off a ledge and then thought better of it and settled. He laughed out loud, not because it was funny but because it was ordinary.

He didn't hear Colm come up; he never did. Colm had a way of showing up like a thought you had decided to have. He held out a hand with a paper cup. "Water with slices of lemon because cucumbers are an abomination," he said.

"How did you—"

"I'm everywhere," Colm said. He leaned next to Evan and let their shoulders be parallel. He had always known how to stand in exactly the right place to make you feel like you had a brother even if you didn't think you needed one. "You look less like a deer in a stadium."

"I'm a vole in a library," Evan said. He took the cup. The lemon made the water taste like old books.

"You'll go back to the sky," Colm said without punctuation.

"I will," Evan said, because he didn't know if that was comfort or threat and he didn't have the energy to make it either.

"Do you know why the blimp that lives over by the highway moves so slowly, and why it still scares me even though it's ridiculous?" Colm said.

"No," Evan said, because if you told him magic he would listen.

"It is too big and too quiet. Things that are that big should not be quiet. I know that like I know I shouldn't look straight at the moon when it's full because it will break my neck. You'll go back when you can." He took a breath like he was taking in more than air. "I brought you here for a reason."

"I assumed you brought me here because Tess needed hands and you owe her fourteen things."

"Seventeen, but who's counting." Colm shifted, and when he did a warmth came off him that wasn't weather. It wasn't the cup. It wasn't the alley. It was him, and if Evan had been an animal he would have sidled closer to it and then hated himself for that. "I wanted you to be in a room where making a world does not ask for blood."

Evan, who had been about to smile something away, stopped. "What do you mean," he said, but not like a question.

"I mean, you go up and you make a world every time, and that world demands a tithe. Sometimes the tithe is coffee and sleep. Sometimes it's something else. I wanted to put you in a world that took softer currency for a while."

He looked at Colm, for the first time that day looked all the way. "You talk like a man who's always selling. But it's for me, isn't it. The sell is to me."

"Most of my selling is for me," Colm said with that little sideways offense at himself that made him charming. "This one, I think I get nothing from. Except you."

"Leave it to you to make that sound like a trick." He paused. "Thanks."

"You don't have to thank me," Colm said, which was always suspicious. He reached up and absently plucked at the brick with his nails. Dust made a small cloud that was golden for a second. He smiled at it like a king.

Evan was tired. Tired in the way that isn't sleep but weight. He thought suddenly of those pictures that used to be in science books, of a drop of red magnified, those smooth coins of cells, stacks of them like gummy candy. He felt the room of himself shift. He put his hand on the brick.

"Don't faint on me," Colm said, but lightly.

"I'm not," Evan said; then, surprising himself, he said, "Stay."

"I am not leaving," Colm said, and something in his voice said, I don't.

Later, he would try to remember if any of this had been a clue, if any of this had laid down a strand that could make a net he could pull himself with. He would think of Colm's heat like a foundry, of the way the alley had gone very quiet as if even pigeons had held their breath. He would think of Tess saying "blessing" like she meant it. He would think of the way, on State Street that night, a dog had crossed in front of them and bowed, a solemn, strange bow, before running into the dark.

For now, he breathed next to his brother who was also a stranger and tried to outlast a feeling that had a face and a name. He was at the beginning. He didn't know that yet. He tilted his head and listened to the theater under his feet, the way you listen to a plane: not to what it is doing, but to the change in what it is doing.

"Places," Tess called from inside, her voice carrying like a cathedral bell through the brick. The word sounded different, like someone had hung a ribbon on it. Evan wiped his hand on his jeans. He went in. He turned one light to half, and then another, and then let the dark take the edges. He found the "Go" with his thumb without looking, the way you find the pulse in your own wrist when you want to know if you're still here. He clicked. The stage breathed, and the story, whatever it was, came toward him with open hands.

On the third day he learned how to be a clock. That was what Tess called it when she walked him through the paper tech, a ritual that made theater people look like accountants and feel like generals. They sat at a folding table that had seen other wars and marked time in pencil. The table was covered with paper: the script printed large and broken into blocks, the light cues written in the margins in Tess’s loping hand, sound cues in block letters as if naming them could keep them from going feral. Around them the actors sprawled on the stairs like cats that had agreed to be human for a while. Vee had a pen she stuck behind her ear and forgot and then went searching for, accusing the air of theft. The tall man with the hat had placed the hat on his knee like an old dog. Sophie, who was small and precise, was sewing something that might have been a sleeve or might have been a metaphor; her needle made tiny audible tsks as it moved. Tess tapped the script with a pencil that had teeth dents in it and said, “This is where you become the heartbeat. I say ‘Standby’, you say ‘Lights standing by’ and ‘Sound standing by,’ and then I say ‘Go’ and you move the world. If the world does not move we pretend we meant it. That is ninety percent of the job. The other ten percent is making people drink water and putting out little fires I start.”

He liked the formality, because it gave his body something to dress itself in. There was relief in being allowed to be literal. He drew a little box in his notebook each time a cue happened, just to see it appear. He wrote “LX” for lights and “SND” for sounds and “PRJ” for the projector they insisted was not a projector but an instrument, and then he found himself shading them like a child fills in a coloring book when he needs the edges to matter. He liked the way Tess handed him the baton without any ceremony and with all of it. “You’re the only one looking at the whole,” she said, “which means you are allowed to be boring. Boring is underrated.”

They went through “Rend” on paper, and even just that felt like a kind of violence softened by instruction. It was a piece about tearing and mending, which was the kind of sentence that made Arthur’s mouth twitch in disdain when he read it in the community calendar and then circled the showtime anyway. It had been built from interviews and arguments and an afternoon when the company had brought in old blankets and ripped them and then stitched them and then tried not to cry about things that were not blankets. There was a scene where Vee stood with a pair of scissors and did not cut anything while speaking a litany of all the times in her life she had wanted to open a seam and put her head in. There was a scene where the tall man in the hat told a story about his grandmother’s hands, and he undressed the hat from his head and held it like a bowl and showed you it was empty, and then at the end of the scene he turned it over and something fell out you had not seen him put there. There was a section with a table and the kind of lights that look like they belong in an interrogation; Tess wanted those to blink and not blink, to threaten blinking. There was, in Act Two, they insisted on calling it Act Two though no one sat long enough to deserve Greek, a sequence with red fabric that moved like water when six of them moved together, a river that was actually six arms and something about bodies making bodies.

“Here,” Tess said, her pencil on a line that said in his own looping handwriting, because she had made him write it, INFINITE RED FABRIC ENTERS LIKE A SECRET. “You will want to go early because it’s beautiful. Don’t. Let them carry it to you.”

He swallowed and nodded and wrote, “Don’t help beauty,” which made Vee look over his shoulder and laugh without cruelty. “You’re going to be all right, Captain,” she said, calling him that like a joke she knew still had teeth in it.

They did spacing, which was less about space than about watching bodies learn to trust tape. He learned a new palette of words. “Spike” was a piece of tape telling a table where it would be later; “spiking” became holy. “Hold” was what you said when someone was about to die or when a chair leg made an awful sound; when you said “Hold,” the air obeyed you. Tess gave him the “Hold” with a look, like you might give someone you like the keys to your car because you think their nervousness will keep them from doing stupid things. “You don’t say it to feel large,” she told him in the dark between cues, where their faces glowed with emergency light and a feeling like belonging. “You say it because something needs you to.”

At lunch he followed Vee out the side door into the sliver of alley that pretended it was a patio if you squinted. The sun made a rectangle on the asphalt like a trap you would gladly walk into and then stand in forever. She had a sandwich whose bread looked too good for someone who said “I’m broke” as if that were a choice she had made with pride. He had the last of one of June’s soups in a jar and a plastic spoon with a crack like a fault line. They leaned against the dumpster the way you lean against a problem and decide you will not be the one to solve it but you will keep it company. Vee said, “Tess told me something but I think she told everyone because she is nosy and also kind.”

“And what did that change in the universe,” he asked, aiming for lightness and landing close enough.

“That you flew,” Vee said, “and that you’re not flying because your head remembered something it didn’t want to remember. She said you’re not a hero. She meant it like a compliment. We don’t have much use for them here.”

He ate a spoon of soup and felt its heat slide down like a truce. “I like jobs where I’m a hinge,” he said. “You turn me and a thing opens. That’s all. Pilots get told we’re gods because people don’t think about the plane when it’s doing what they want. I liked being the hinge better.”

Vee nodded like someone who collected nods. “I used to want to be the door,” she said. “And then I was. It was too much. Everyone coming through. Everyone slamming you when they were angry. Hinges get to hide.”

“You say that like a vow,” he said. He wanted to ask her what she had been the door to, but he had learned enough about Vee in three days to know she counted questions given to her and returned change later.

Back inside, they started again. He stood behind the board. He found that there was a prayer in “Standby,” especially when Tess made the word a sigh and not an order. “Standby cue thirty-one through thirty-eight,” she said, and in the booth his treble repeated it, and in repeating it turned it into something that would happen. At cue forty-two they had their first accident, which Tess took like a gift from some god she didn’t believe in because it meant they had met that god early in the run.

“Hold,” said the universe, except it was the tall man slaughtering his alphabet in a cough that was more like a bark. He had knelt to adjust a piece of tape he had decided he didn’t like and came up too fast. The hat let out a little exclamation point and fell. He put a hand to his face and then took it down and there was, inevitable and delicate and unstoppable, a slickness under his nostrils that gleamed before it fell.

Evan did not know an amount of red could be so precise and so ruinous at once. It wasn’t a gush, it wasn’t the obscene hand that had spread across a windshield, but his body didn’t consult nuance. His chest unlaced itself and tried to leave; his vision contracted to a tunnel that saw only that one drop. He had an absurd thought that if he could make it not drop he would be back in the plane before the shudder, before the spray. He put his hand on the console and felt the hard edges of faders like banisters. Tess’s voice reached him from a far country that was one step away. She was saying “Hold,” and then she was saying “House to half please,” and then she was in the aisle, and then she was a hand on the tall man’s arm, and then she was elbows and cloth and people breathing the breath of what now.

He heard himself say “Hold,” late and echoing, like he’d heard himself say it the first time he had told a plane to stop. The word entered him and moved the air, and the moving air did a tiny thing to his rib cage: it reminded his ribs that they, too, were banisters. He took a breath and felt only half of it, which was more than a quarter and thus counted as progress. He reached blindly for the headset that hung on a nail, because if he could put something over his ears it would be like putting his mother’s palm on his head, that old warmth.

“First aid kit?” Vee said from somewhere to his left, and he could hear in her voice that she wanted to catch it, the drop, with words, and that words were not cups.

“Green room, top of the fridge,” Sophie said, and already her feet were making that sneaker squeak that made all of this seem like a cartoon that would hurt only if you looked sideways at it.

The tall man said, “It’s fine, it’s fine, it always does this,” and he sounded like that at every nosebleed for his whole life, that apology shape. Someone handed him a cloth that used to be white, because every theatre had an item that used to be white and had surrendered. Blood made a dot and then a bigger dot. The iron smell that science says you do not actually smell because smell is not iron but your brain’s idea of iron arrived like a memory of pennies. Evan’s wrist throbbed the way it had in the cockpit when Magda had used that perilous voice.

“Head down, pinch the bridge,” Tess said, and then, “Don’t tilt back, you’re not trying to irrigate your throat,” and then to Sophie, “Gloves, get him gloves because we’re pretending to be professionals.”

Evan found himself gripping the board. He told his heart, absurdly, that he would be with it in a moment. He opened the drawer to his right—Sheila’s drawer of things she hadn’t yet sorted and would now be his to sort—and found tape and cough drops and a box of nitrile. He put a glove on because doing one thing he had done before could sometimes persuade the body to follow; he had put on gloves in planes and in kitchens and when Arthur had taught him to sand a board just so. The glove snapped around his wrist with a sound that took the room into its mouth and softened its corners. He moved down the steps like a man in a pool, determined to reach the other side. He crouched by the tall man, who was saying he was fine and whose face contradicted that in a dozen little shards.

“Here,” Evan said, his voice without echo, “I’ve got you.” He could feel the tremor in his own hand, a low rpm hum. He could also feel the weight of what this was, which was not an emergency in any universe where they had invented words for real emergencies. He put the glove on himself and then got the tall man to tilt forward just enough that the body could do the job it had always done. He pinched with the tall man’s fingers, counting in a quiet rote that surprised him: “One two three four,” as if there were a lever that wanted to come up at two hundred. “You’re good,” he said. “You’re doing it. Stay with us.”

Vee handed him a cold compress from a little packet that must have lived in that green room’s nest for years. He pressed it gently to the bridge with his knuckles so he didn’t have to look straight at the red that was not yet red, that was still a wetness. The tall man’s breath slowed, and in the slowing there was a sound like rails taken up out of the road when winter ends. The dot on the cloth quit its ambition and went ordinary. The iron smell did its quiet exit, the way smells leave as if insulted you noticed them in the first place.

“Look at that,” Tess said, her praise a dry palm. “A man who takes a command. Can we keep you in the booth and also in the apocalypse.”

“Only if I get to write the checklist,” he said, breath returning in increments. His knee hurt from the crouch and he welcomed the hurt like a hand on his shoulder. He handed the compress to the tall man, who was called Marcus, he remembered then, because it mattered now. “You good?”

“I’m embarrassed,” Marcus said, as if that were a diagnosis. “I always, if it’s dry and then I bend too fast.”

“Hydrate,” Sophie said, the way someone says “repent.”

“Back in ten,” Tess announced to the room at large, as if she hadn’t already stolen back the ten with her competence. She looked at Evan while everyone dispersed, and he saw in her face that relief that is tinged with guilt: you thanked whatever had made the accident small and given you a chance to practice your kindness, and you hated that you were the sort of animal who could be grateful for proof of your own capacities.

He went back up to the booth and did not sit until he could sit ordinary. He put his hands flat on the console and let the ridges of the fader track press lines into his palms, geography he could carry into the next room. The word “bleed,” which had been a siren, subsided into the background noise of language. He felt a small swell of pride, and then a wash of shame at the pride, and then he allowed both to be there because he could not spend his life refusing emotions their passports.

They resumed, and the red fabric sequence came later, and it was, to his horror and pleasure, as beautiful as he had feared. The six of them came in with the cloth pooled in their hands, and for a second it looked insolent and dead. Then they lifted and the thing became a river, it became a weather system, it became every curtain you had ever hidden behind and every artery that had ever pumped and every flag you had ever been asked to salute and couldn’t. It moved like he wished he felt: continuously, without snag, making a surface for light to play on. He did not go early, as instructed. He waited until Tess’s breath next to him changed, a slight click in it, and then he pressed “Go” and the low side light turned the red into a kind of velvet dream. He might have closed his eyes for a second because in the dark he imagined the cockpit again, the purple-grey of cloud when the warning light is on and you have to decide. When he opened them he was still in the booth and Marcus was not bleeding and Vee was not cutting anything with her scissors that were always a threat and never the weapon.

At dinner home was a great blousy bowl of spaghetti made by a woman who thought of pasta as a moral stance. June had sauce on her wrist and didn’t notice for twenty minutes because she was telling a story about a man at the bank who had made her laugh by sneezing exactly like a puppy. Arthur pretended not to be charmed and then told them how much money the bank had made off people who couldn’t subtract and then made himself a policeman of garlic bread. Colm arrived late, not because he could not arrive on time but because he believed time was a curve he could lean against and then straighten with his hands. He set a paper bag on the counter like an apology for what he would be later. It contained olives in a container that leaked and two kinds of cheese June would approve of because they didn’t call themselves anything. Colm kissed June’s cheek and touched Arthur’s shoulder with a knuckle. He looked at Evan over the steam like this was another show they had both wandered into without tickets.

“How is the church,” Arthur said to him, and then to Evan, for explanation, “He ministers to the theater people.”

“I am a deacon of poor decisions,” Colm said. He snagged an olive with his fingers and chewed it in a way that made you think olive should pay him rent. “Your boy distinguished himself today.”

“You have informants,” Evan said, and Vee would have liked the way he made the word a dare.

“I have eyes that tell me things,” Colm said. “You didn’t run out of the back of the room and leave a cartoon cutout of yourself in the door. You did a small good thing.”

“It was a nose,” Evan said, and then the words surprised him, came unbidden, “It was not a wing.” He could feel the minute temperature shift that came when you told a room what had hurt you last. Arthur looked at him and did not say a thing. June did the little frown she did when she was about to say too much and then chose not to, an art she had had to practice. Colm nodded as if mentally moving a bead on an abacus.

“Tomorrow,” Colm said lightly to the table in general, “a man will come and ask me to find a dog.”

This was how he was; he dropped a sentence like a small explosive and then watched you not react, and then he knew who you were. June said, “There are posters,” practical, a mother to all lost domesticated creatures.

“They want a particular dog,” Colm said. “A dog that has learned to open the latch on the backyard gate with his teeth. The man says he loves the dog and I believe him because he stopped for a full two seconds in his telling and looked like someone took his throat away.”

“And what is this to you,” Arthur said, though he was smiling despite himself, because he liked to pretend he was immune to Colm and then wake up to having driven him to a thing and waited with the engine running.

“This is how I make rent,” Colm said, so open you almost forgot to be angry. “I find dear things for people who lost them. Sometimes it is a dog. Sometimes it is a ring they never owned in the first place and will sell to feel noble. Sometimes it is a way to leave without breaking a window. Sometimes it is a furnace repairman who won’t charge three hundred dollars to come and press a reset button. People don’t know how to ask. They know how to list. I like turning lists into requests.”

“You’re a fixer,” Arthur said, professional disgust nicely sanded with affection.

“I am a pointer,” Colm said. He bowed his head to the bowl like he thought it was holy. “I stand in a room and sometimes the air moves for me. It’s ridiculous, really. Do you have more bread, June.”

After dinner, when Arthur washed dishes in his methodical way and June triaged the dry with a towel she swore made plates shinier than the machine, Colm stood at the back door like he’d been asked to guard the night. Evan went out with him into the hum. Fireflies began to assert themselves in the yard, insolent punctuation. The neighbor’s maple was a gossipy silhouette. The air had that sugary thickness Ohio got when it remembered the cornfields around it and decided to marinate you.

Colm lit a cigarette and then passed it to Evan, and Evan made a face but took it because it was old and stupid and had a taste like some memory he couldn’t name. He didn’t smoke, which was why in moments like this he did; he liked choosing his poisons when the others were choosing him. Colm watched the smoke lift like a thought having second thoughts.

“I saw a thing today,” Colm said finally, in that way he had of making the thing he was about to say feel like an ethical problem rather than a story. “I wanted your take, which is either rich or pathetic depending on the hour.”

“As if my take is anything,” Evan said, blowing smoke into a shape and then being ashamed of himself for enjoying the shape.

“Downtown, the new coffee place that believes chairs should be a lesson,” Colm said. “A boy was standing with a leaflet in his fingers and talking to a woman who had turned her face away. He was talking softly, which is a trick, and he was making the leaflet into a promise. He said the word family four times and the word tired once. I wanted to stand between them because the leaflet had too many exclamation points. I wanted to ask the boy who was tired, him or the woman, because that matters. And then—” He paused, not for effect, but to be exact. “Then the boy flinched at nothing. Like the air hit him. He looked past the woman for a second, and then he folded the leaflet backwards and he left it on the counter like a tip. The woman cried in the coffee smell and then ordered a drink that was nothing but sugar and milk. I saw that and I thought, I can stand in rooms and point all day, but sometimes the room points back.”

Evan considered that. The fireflies made grammar of the yard. “Maybe the room has better manners than we do,” he said. “Maybe the room knows when a thing is too much to carry.”

Colm smiled. “That is comforting,” he said. “And also a little sad. I prefer the version where something in the room grows teeth when I ask it to.” He dropped the cigarette and squashed it with his toe and then, because he was himself, put the stub in the little tin June kept for that purpose as if he had been born knowing to respect tins.

They were quiet for a while. The quiet between them had become something new; it was not the silence of two boys in different corners of the same house, it was not the silence of two men who hadn’t met each other properly yet. It was a silence that was a bridge under construction, ropes being thrown, a little sway, a little triumph at every knot.

The next day Tess made them do the show with everything but an audience. “It’s called a dress rehearsal, though god forbid anyone wears anything nice,” she said. She had a knack for making you feel like you were part of a tradition older than your birth and also brand-new. They put on the lights in the order he had memorized. He wrote a small prayer for himself in the margins of the cue sheet: “Standby to not panic.” He put his pen behind his ear and then reached for it and it wasn’t there, and he laughed to himself because of Vee, because he had borrowed her habit and found it empty. At the half-hour he said “Half hour” into a microphone that made his voice sound like a version of himself he could trust. The word traveled through hallways and stairwells and touched people he couldn’t see. He thought of departure gates and the way certain words make bodies move. He thought of Magda’s hand on his wrist and of the maintenance man’s rag and of the ridiculous grace of a nose bleeding itself out. He stood in the booth and thought he might be almost fine. This was not a promise. It was a place to stand.

They ran. In Act One, Vee’s scissors flashed, and the light caught an old nick on her knuckle that had scarred itself into a white comma. He wanted to ask what it had been; he wanted to say, “Me too,” even though his comma lived in a place the light had a hard time finding. In Act One, a prop glass rolled and showed its dirty bottom and Marcus kicked it softly toward its spike without looking and Evan loved him for that. In Act One, Tess said “Go” three beats later than he would have, and he learned something about patience he let creep into his bones.

Between Acts, a young man from the back of house brought in a tub of liquid with the caution of someone who had been given a baby and a bomb. “Blood,” he announced, because in theater you called a thing by its name so there would be no surprise later when it stained. The tub was cheap plastic and had a lid with a snap. The stuff inside was opaque maroon, too much chocolate syrup, a tug of corn. He had to test it, Tess said, because they would flick a finger into it in Act Two and paint a line on a cloth, a symbolic thing that would read as obvious if it were the wrong viscosity.

He looked at the tub the way you look at an ex you haven’t seen since you were a worse person. He took a breath and opened the snap and let the smell meet his face. It smelled like midnights in kitchens, like pancakes at three a.m. It smelled like children. He found that the part of him that had braced for iron stood down except for the guards who were never off. He stirred with a paint stick and watched the surface pull and let go. Vee came to stand next to him and did not crowd him. She dipped her finger as if she were baptizing herself into mischief. She painted a line on the air, then wiped it on a cloth, and the cloth accepted it. “Looks like a cartoon,” she said. “Good.”

He laughed because relief had that shape in him. “I can do cartoons,” he said. “I just don’t like realism.” She looked at him out of the corner of her eye as if testing whether he knew he had made a joke and taken some of the sting out of it.

“Thanks for yesterday,” Marcus said an hour later, passing him a coffee as if bribing him to be nice again. “That was— I hate it, you know, when my body decides to be stupid in public.”

“We all hate that,” Evan said, accepting the coffee and trying to like it as much as the kindness. He took a sip and grimaced because the cup thought it was coffee and was lying. Marcus laughed a little and patted his arm awkwardly and then went to find his hat, which he had mislaid again in the exact place Tess had told him not to.

By Friday, the day they would let a real roomful of strangers enter and turn them into an audience, the Evergreen had taken on that humming-jelly quality that theaters get when they are about to be genuine. The lobby had been mopped within an inch of its life and somehow still smelled like shoe. The bathrooms had been attended to with a brush and an ancient rag; Sophie had folded the paper towels into a triangle because she believed in small excellences even in rooms where no one cared. Tess walked around with a roll of gaff tape stuck to her wrist like a bracelet of authority. Evan put fresh batteries in mics and then put fresh batteries next to the fresh ones because he had learned that gods shriek without warning. He called the half and then the fifteen and then the five and each time the numbers felt realer, like going down in an airplane and seeing real houses.

At five, June and Arthur showed up in seats they had not paid for because Tess had growled that she would murder anyone who sold a comp to the mother of the new boy who saved a nose. June gooey-eyed the space as if it were the crib of a new baby and not a room that had held more ghosts than babies. Arthur sat as if he had never allowed a chair to tell him where to put his legs. Colm arrived two minutes before lights out, because he would never miss an entrance if someone would clap. He stood in the back at first, a habit, then took a seat when he realized someone else would take it. He had dressed in a sweater that women had probably knitted for him with their eyes. He watched Evan’s booth like he could see through walls. When the lights went to half he became a shape in the dark that was in on a joke.

They started. The tiny edge of fear became a wave and then a lake and then a table he could set a drink on. He said “Standby” and they stood by. He said “Go” and the going happened. In the alley the night before he had told Colm he was a hinge; now he felt like a switch on the body of the theater, one of those small slick toggles with ridges meant for blind fingers. He listened to the audience laugh in a place where he had expected them to and not laugh where he had hoped they might; he listened to the intake of breath when the red fabric river happened, which was sound enough to pay everyone in the room for a week if they lived on breath. He did not mess up a single cue; that sentence was his and he took it home in his mouth and held it there for later when he would need something sweet.

After the show the room did that sloppy slow-motion celebration theaters love: someone clapped too long in a sincere way that made someone else uncomfortable; a man hugged the wrong person; a woman cried and made it funny. Stranger faces came up the aisle and told Tess what the show had done to them, as if Tess were God and had to be told. June hugged three actors and told them she had seen their souls, which, coming from her, sounded like a thing she could actually do. Arthur found a chair and told it about a lighting cue he would have done differently because he could not help himself. Colm stood in a spot the light found and let it and did not apologize.

Evan stood at the rail of the booth until his hands stopped wanting work. He looked at Vee, who was being congratulated by a woman with a jaw like judgment, and Vee endured it like someone who had decided not to be cut by certain knives anymore. He could feel in his pocket the slip of paper Tess had given him with three words on it, the first he had been paid in besides drink tickets: “You belong here.” It was a trap and it was a gift and he had no idea how to unwrap it.

On the walk home with Colm through the soft-drunk summer streets, someone they didn’t know stepped into their path and stepped back and then stepped in again, an indecision like a dance move invented by accident. He was a man of the kind Arthur called a “punctuation person”—someone who appeared in life like a comma and a question mark at once. He had the wiry look of a person who had never met a straight line. He said, “You’re him,” to Colm, and Colm’s back did something small, a readiness, but his face stayed as open as a church door.

“Sometimes,” Colm said. “Depends on the hour.”

“There’s a thing wants you,” the man said. He looked at Evan too as if measuring his ability to be useful or to ruin something by breathing on it. He had a smell about him, sweat and night and old, old books.

“There are always things,” Colm said lightly, and the light in his voice was a screen door that would slam shut if you were not careful.

“This one is related to your boy,” the man said, and the way he said “boy” was older than the streetlights. “You know the river, the one with the rocks that racket like teeth. Something left a mark by the bridge. A red. A making. It isn’t the usual paint. it isn’t church. It’s the other. They want you because you’re small enough to ask and big enough to see. And if you don’t, it keeps asking.”

Evan felt it as a cold at the base of his skull, not his blood thing, not his pilot thing either, a new tremor that belonged to his bones. He looked at Colm and saw that the warmth around him had turned from a summer thing to a cookfire. Colm laughed, a sound like a man being polite to a god who has just appeared in the wrong shirt. “Tell whoever ‘they’ are that I’ll walk by the bridge after I tuck in the kid,” he said, and he said “kid” and the man looked at Evan like he was a puzzle he did not want to solve.

“If it spreads,” the man said, “and it will, you’ll wish you went when asked.”

“Everyone always does,” Colm said softly. “Run along. Drink water. Don’t look straight at what the sky is doing tonight.”

The man went; he didn’t really go, he diminished until he was part of the block and then part of the block’s memory. Evan stood and put his hands in his pockets because he hadn’t known what else to do since he was thirteen. “Is this your other work,” he said, not keeping all the skepticism out of his voice, because if something was going to be nonsense he wanted to know before he had to clean up after it.

“It is all the same work,” Colm said, so tired in that moment that Evan wanted to put a blanket on his shoulders and tell him to sit. “People misplace things. Dogs, rings, courage. Sometimes the things misplace themselves. Sometimes the road ruins the road and you have to ask it to stop.”

“You’re kidding,” Evan said, because his body had a reflex and it was to push away the idea that rooms pointed back.

“I am an instrument,” Colm said, and for one sliver of a second his eyes did that molten trick and for one sliver of a second Evan knew what it would be to be a room that had just been asked. Then Colm’s face closed again, and he was only a man in a sweater. “Come if you want. Stay if you’re saner than me.”

Evan wanted, which surprised him. He wanted to stand by a river and see whether the water could talk. He wanted to be with his brother even if his brother was about to walk into a nonsense he had made up to survive himself. He also wanted to go to bed and make himself a small person under a quilt in a house where June left lights on like wards. He was two men and a boy and a hinge and a switch and a person who wanted to be bored. He said, “I’ll walk,” and heard how his voice made it sound like a fact.

They went down past the storefronts with their names like herbs and apothecaries, past the bar where Max sometimes sat on his one night off and pretended not to be dispatch. The night had a bruise in it. The river announced itself before they could see it; it had a mouth the town had taught it to use. When they got to the bridge, a municipal thing that had dipped its toes in history and then been replaced and then dipped again, Evan felt the hairs on his arms decide they had been painted on. He saw, under the bright mean light, a mark. It was at the place where teenagers wrote their names and then pretended it was their fates. It looked like paint in that it was red, but not the red you buy at Lowe’s because it matches your idea of barn. It had that weird blue in it that real red has. It was also dry and also looked wet. It had been spread with a hand by someone who had never spread paint before on purpose.

Colm stepped closer and then stopped with respect like you stop at the edge of a sanctuary when you don’t know where the candles are. He did not put his hand out. Good, Evan thought, because if you touch the stupid thing I will have to carry you home and explain to June that you died of idiot. The cord in the back of Colm’s hand stood up anyway, like it wanted to try the dark. “Someone made a door,” Colm said, and he said it matter-of-fact the way you might say “The soffit is rotten.” “They don’t know how to close doors. They’ll say they didn’t mean it and then act hurt when the wind comes in.”

“You want me to get you a rag,” Evan said, a blend of mockery and care that had been their pattern since the first time they had shared a bathroom. “You want me to pretend this is paint and you want to scrape.”

“I want you to stand where you’re standing,” Colm said, and the voice—there it was—thickened, gained a grain. “You make rooms steady. It helps.”

“You’re a lunatic,” Evan said, with love, and took half a step anyway into the posture of a man who has decided he can catch something if it falls. He looked at the mark and hated it for looking like a hand he had seen on glass. He could feel a pulse under the bridge in the water or in himself; he could not tell which and laughed quietly because distinction is for days off.

Colm took a breath, big and slow. He reached into his pocket and brought out not a rag but a stub of chalk like a teacher who doesn’t want to teach your child so much as draw a protective circle around her. He drew on the concrete next to the red without touching it. He drew a shape that was humble, a circle with a little dent in it, like a cup under a drip. He muttered, and Evan realized with a shock that he had heard the words before. They were a child’s nonsense about not letting the bogeyman under the bed: “Stay out, stay there, stay in your house.” He had said it when he was eight while June brushed his hair and he had asked about his father. How did Colm know it. How did Colm have a piece of their kitchen in his mouth.

The chalk line wasn’t much. It was already smeared from the damp that lived under a bridge. But when Colm finished the little circle and put the chalk back in his pocket and exhaled, some awful pressure in the air gave up its little show of power and went off to find a lazier boy to bother. The red looking-wet looked less wet, because the world had decided not to stare at it. The river made a little satisfied sound, as if a pebble had been moved to a better place.

“You and your toys,” Evan said, the words as a way to not say what he had felt.

“You and your buttons,” Colm said back, smiling that crooked his good teeth could not fix.

They walked home without speaking about it. Near the house, the dog from the previous night crossed in front of them and bowed again, as if it had taken the night class and learned to greet kings. Evan wanted to apologize to the animal for all the people he had been and not been. He wanted to say to the world, I am trying. June had left the porch light on. It made a small pool on the boards. He stepped into that pool and felt, for the second time in as many days, that his body belonged to him in a way that might last for the space of a cup of tea.

In bed, with the window cracked and the Ohio summer wanting in, he did not dream of birds or of red or of chalk. He dreamed of a switch, the old kind with a Bakelite knob, ridged under his thumb. He dreamed that the switch was part of a machine he could not see all of and that somehow, impossibly, when he pressed it, two rooms lit at once: the theater and the cockpit, one light warmer than the other, both good. In the morning he would wake and make coffee and be someone who went to work; not the work everyone expected, not the work he had thought would always be the only thing for him, but work nonetheless. He would measure his day in standbys and gos, in breath and in chalk, in the ordinary acquaintance of people who did not expect to find god but were not insulted when a small god found them anyway. He would walk into the Evergreen and be the man who made the dark happen on purpose and then bring it up, who let a story come and put its hand out and not flinch when it did. He would, because he had no other way, listen for the change.

By morning the bridge felt like an idea he could have dreamed, the way small dangerous things do when you place a window between them and the sun. June put eggs on a plate like she always had and told him a story about a neighbor who had planted zinnias in a circle so tight the flowers were suffocating each other and how she’d walked over with a spoon and separated them gently as if they were toddlers, and Arthur argued with the weather on television as if its predictions were personal slurs. Colm looked the same and not the same, the warmth around him banked but insistent, and he picked up his coffee with both hands the way he did when something had tugged at his edges in the night. Evan let the ordinary make its case, nodded when June told him to take a banana because potassium was not optional, and pretended not to watch his brother for signs of anything a language didn’t have words for yet.

He walked to the theater alone because he wanted to see the town in daylight after standing under its bridge at midnight, and because it felt like a dare he could win without anyone witnessing the wobble in his step. The baristas at the corner place were children with rings in places his grandmother would have called delicate; one of them had a bandage at his knuckle and the sight of the dirty gauze made Evan’s throat dip and rise like a fish. He bought coffee and did not look at the drip on the lid that made a small Rosetta of brown on the white; he wiped it with his sleeve and told himself that whatever ritual that was, it was his to choose. Inside the Evergreen Tess had a roll of tickets around her wrist and a pen behind her ear and the aura of a woman about to commit to a battle that would end in confetti and bills, and she said, “You’re early in a way that makes me think you slept badly, which is fine, I slept like an ambassador between two warring states.”

They walked the building together the way pilots walk a plane, touching things not because touch changes them but because touch tells you when change has already happened. Tess bent and ran her fingers along the edge of the stage and came up with a splinter that she kissed and put on her tongue because that was the sort of superstition that was half a laugh and half a sacrament.
